Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @brentstirton // Supported by Nat Geo Society/Wyss Campaign for Nature committed to protecting 30% of the planet by 2030. // Virunga National Park, Democratic Republic of Congo: Africa’s conservation rangers are facing tremendous pressure. Due to the economic impact of COVID-19, there is less philanthropic funding available for conservation— and that's likely to continue well into 2021. As a result, these guardians face increased threats and fewer resources, putting themselves and vulnerable animals at greater risk. This image is early morning in the central section of Virunga, one of the most difficult places for rangers. This year alone they have lost fifteen rangers, with nine wounded. This is not the only place where rangers are at risk as they defend our global wildlife heritage. #ForWildlifeRangers #conservation #virunganationalpark #africanparksnetwork #campaignfornature

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown / A wedding procession at a Catholic Church in Lulingu, South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo. Roughly half the Congolese population is Catholic, with six archdioceses and 41 dioceses. Described by academic Michael G. Schatzberg as the "only truly national institution apart from the state,” Catholic schools have educated over 60 percent of the nation's primary school students and more than 40 percent of its secondary students. The church owns and manages an extensive network of hospitals, schools, and clinics, as well as many diocesan economic enterprises, including farms, ranches, stores, and artisans' shops. Follow @michaelchristopherbrown for more human stories from around the world.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: After the storm, the rain created what seemed like an endless natural reflection pool over the salt flats just outside Salt Lake City, Utah. @Renan_Ozturk cherishes time spent at home with his dog @BalooInTheWild while not traveling or on assignment. This was such a contagious moment of pure joy as he took off across the expanse! #joy #baloointhewild #dogsofinstagram

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @beverlyjoubert / For the "unadapted," a salt lake can be a hostile place. But for this brightly-hued flock soaring over a saline expanse in Kenya, it’s a perfect fit—with the added bonus of very little competition for space and food from other species. Flamingos have evolved a remarkable toolkit of adaptations that make them quite comfortable in extreme wetland environments—but that specialized lifestyle can also make them vulnerable. When human activity begins to threaten flamingos’ uniquely inhospitable watery havens—as is the case in some parts of Africa—the future survival of these immense flocks is put at risk, too. #flamingo #birds #birdsofinstagram

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid / Lion under red light, Ol Kinyei Conservancy, Masai Mara, Kenya. For
tracking wildlife after dark in the bush, many of the trackers I work with use a simple combination of the color of the eyeshine and the height of the eyes and their width apart, markers that immediately identify the species in the absence of seeing the animal itself. The eyeshine is caused by a reflective layer behind the retina called the tapetum lucid, which sends light back through the retina, increasing the light available to be captured in an image. Animals that possess these layers, such as lions, have far better nocturnal vision than those that don’t—for example, us. It's this reflected light that causes eyeshine and allows us to track them with artificial light. To see more follow me @chancellordavid @ewasolions @porinicamps #masaimara #kenya #lion #africa #communityconservation

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Video by @bertiegregory / A male gray wolf catches our scent on the west coast of the Hudson Bay, in Canada. On this morning we had been following a pack of wolves for a few hours, but ended up losing them in the deep snow and thick willows. As our small team chatted about our next move, we spotted this male following the exact same path of the pack, with his nose to the floor. Whether he was a member of the pack or an outsider trailing them, we'll never know. These wolves don’t often see people and live in an area where wolves aren’t persecuted. As a result, they are bold and curious. After realizing we weren’t particularly interesting, he trotted off. Follow @bertiegregory for more wildlife adventures. #wildlife #animals #wolves #wolf #snow

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag / Coatepec, Veracruz, Mexico: A portrait of the leader of the clown performance group Cuadrilla de Juquilita. His clothing features the likeness of the Virgin of Guadalupe, the country's patron saint. Follow me at @lujanag to learn more about this story and my work.
