Post description: Photo by @erintrieb / One year ago, in November 2019, thousands of Iraqis organized to protest Iraq’s sectarian political system and government corruption. For several months Iraqi youth occupied central Baghdad, where hundreds of protestors were killed and thousands injured, prompting Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi to resign. COVID-19 brought Iraq’s protests to a halt, with the rise of curfews and social distancing, but the impact of the protests continues. Here protestors take cover behind a concrete barricade after Iraqi security forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets. For more human stories from around the world follow @erintrieb.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Karla Gachet @kchete77 / Field workers in California’s Central Valley endure high heat while picking our country’s produce. Blas Orozco picks grapes that will be made into raisins. The workers get paid by quantity, so speed and strength are of great importance. According to law, when the temperature reaches 80°F (26°C), there should be shade for workers to take breaks. They should be allowed to take a paid, five-minute (or as long as needed) break if they start feeling bad. When the temperature reaches 95°F (35°C), they should be given a 10-minute break. #HEAT #CentralValley #migrantfarmworkers

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Pete McBride @pedromcbride / Octopus's Garden: After seeing the documentary about a man’s year-long learning experience with a wild octopus, I happened to encounter one of these remarkably intelligent creatures the next day. Aside from their famous camouflaging abilities, including matching the color and texture of their environment and using black ink to cloak their escape, octopuses have hundreds of suckers along their eight arms. Each sucker individually aids with touch and smell thanks to thousands of neurons, which act like a brain in their arms. For more wild places, follow @pedromcbride. #antigua #diving #underwater #octopus #ocean

Photos by @paoloverzone / For two decades, a menagerie of frozen animal carcasses has passed through the CT scanners of Ohio's O'Bleness Hospital, including this Siamese crocodile. Larry Witmer, an anatomist at nearby Ohio University, uses the resulting scans to reconstruct the internal anatomy hidden within the skulls of extinct dinosaurs.

Siamese crocodiles are critically endangered; this individual died of natural causes.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Scientists have learned more about dinosaurs in the last 25 years alone than in the previous two centuries. In our newest augmented-reality experience, capture life-size dinosaurs in your space and learn about the latest findings that have upended what we know about the ancient beasts. You can also use the selfie mode and share videos of yourself as the dinosaur. Thanks to groundbreaking science, we’ve learned that this dinosaur, Deinonychus, raised eggs like modern-day birds. Check out our Instagram story to try out the experience. #reimaginingdinosaurs #ar

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: A magnificent aurora crown moves overhead, changing color and shape every second. Night sky photographer @babaktafreshi recorded this time-lapse sequence last year in Iceland, a striking display of the northern lights. Music by composer Barbad Bayat.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner / Florida is home to more non-native species of reptiles and amphibians than anywhere else in the world. The Argentine black and white tegu (Salvator merianae) is another invasive escapee from the pet trade. This fantastic lizard has established breeding populations in Hillsborough County (central Florida) and Miami-Dade County (southern Florida), and all the way up to Georgia.

The species is an omnivore, consuming a variety of plants and small animals, but is especially known for eating the buried eggs of native reptiles. Tegus can grow up to four feet long, survive below-freezing temperatures by burrowing into the ground, and lay an average of 35 eggs a year—they are a potential ecological hazard.

University of Florida biologists are working toward the removal and management of the species in the Everglades ecosystem. An extensive trap line is baited with eggs and checked daily. Some of the trapped animals get re-released with radio telemetry transmitters in order to track their movements and learn more about habitat usage and home range. Thank you to the amazing team of biologists at University of Florida for doing the work they do.

For more stories on the intersections between humans and animals, follow @kaigner. #tegu #invasivespecies #lizard #florida

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Cristina Mittermeier @Mitty / Secure in its foothold among the tidal flats of British Columbia's shores, this lone female sea wolf paused to gaze at me. I’ve spent hours waiting in the cold rain with my camera in hand for these coastal canines to grow comfortable enough to reveal their secret lives to me. But once I gained their trust, their highly inquisitive nature became immediately apparent. Rain wolves are very affectionate with one another, and the bond between pack members is unbreakable. They subsist almost exclusively on marine life, a behavior so unique that taxonomists are considering classifying their population as a separate species from their inland kin. However, these incredibly unique animals are afforded no formal protection. I hope to change that through sharing my experiences with them and encouraging people to see wolves as socially complex beings, not just predators. Follow me @Mitty to learn more about these elusive animals and how we can help protect them.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @beverlyjoubert / Can we fix our broken relationship with nature before it’s too late? We’ve lost a heart-breaking 68% of global wildlife populations to human activity in the past 50 years alone. In some parts of the world, the losses are even more pronounced. We’ve significantly altered almost every corner of the planet’s surface. This doesn’t just pose a lethal threat to the ever expanding ranks of endangered species and ecosystems all around us. It threatens our own survival too. It is easy, and at times perhaps convenient, to overlook those countless services, big and small, that the natural world provides –until they run out. #biodiversity #fornature #conservation

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @acacia.johnson / As I sat with my father at the creek where my parents worked as bear guides in the 1980s, this female brown bear descended from the hillside, approaching to within a few meters away. She fished, ate, and napped next to us for hours, completely at peace with our presence.

In Alaska's McNeil State Game Refuge, the world's largest congregations of brown bears have been habituated to coexist with small groups of guided viewers who visit during summer. But these bears are threatened by the proposed Pebble Mine, which could risk poisoning the ecosystem and fracture the habitat the bears need to thrive.

If we truly protect our remaining wilderness and the abundance of land that feeds us all, these kinds of humbling and awe-inspiring encounters can be preserved for generations to come. But the choice is ours to make. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond. #alaska #brownbears #pebblemine

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown / “The moon jellyfish can age backward, form hordes of clones, and regenerate lost body parts….a hole rips through his body, but seals up and heals completely….an appendage is sliced off; the tissues grow back perfectly. He is capable of extreme regeneration, perhaps even immortality.” -National Geographic. During a visit to the Sea Center in Santa Barbara, California, with my daughter, Poppy, we saw these beautiful moon jellyfish. One of the joys of fatherhood has been showing her the wonders of the natural world. Follow me @michaelchristopherbrown for more human stories from around the world.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @estherhorvath / This may be the northernmost Halloween party, in the central Arctic Ocean on the MOSAiC expedition. As I document research in the polar regions, I'm also interested in how people spend their free time when they're so far from civilization. Ronny Engelmann, a scientist with the Leibniz Institute for Tropospheric Research, donned a space blanket to become C-3PO for a Halloween party on the icebreaker Polarstern. Dressing up was mandatory. And since expedition participants did not bring along costumes, they had to improvise with materials found on the ship.

Please follow @estherhorvath for more polar stories.

Post description: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / Colorful lupine flowers carpet the valley floor of the Patagonian Andes in southern Chile. The spring bloom is currently underway in this seemingly untouched part of the world.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Pete McBride @pedromcbride / Visitors climb “Big Daddy,” the tallest dune in the Sossusvlei region of Namibia, at 325 meters. The Namib Desert aptly means “vast place” and covers three million hectares. Fog is the primary source of water in this UNESCO World Heritage Site, which supports a unique range of species that constantly adapt to microhabitats and ecological niches. To see more unique perspectives of remote places, follow @pedromcbride. #aerial #nature #desert #Namibia #Africa

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @lucalocatelliphoto / A skier descends the artificial slopes of Amager Bakke, Copenhagen’s waste-to-energy power plant. Claiming to be the world’s cleanest incinerator, Amager Bakke doubles as a learning space for sustainability and circularity and an public outdoor space—a centerpiece of the Danish capital’s skyline that provides hot water and electricity to the city.

Incinerators are seen as an end-of-pipe solution to get rid of our waste, which is why Amager Bakke has been designed from the ground up to one day be fueled by biomass, making it a promising solution for energy security.

I had the chance to investigate incineration and other examples of energy production in my latest cover story for National Geographic magazine, called the "End of Trash," which covers circular-economy solutions. It has the potential to impact resource use, pollution, and emissions by designing waste out of the production system.

Scientists claim we only have a few years to halt and reverse our overconsumption and our emissions in order to save our changing climate, the natural habitat, and, ultimately, ourselves.

A circular economy is only one of the tools; the truth is there isn't one single solution, yet each one of us can make a big difference being mindful of our choices and staying informed. Through my career I have used photography to tell stories about our environment and how we are learning new ways to live on Earth. Follow me @lucalocatelliphoto. #environment #circulareconomy #amagerbakke #copenhagen #lucalocatelliphoto

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @noralorek / 2020 is the year of nurses and midwives. Here, 48 students attend a lecture during a midwifery program in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Most of the young women who have chosen the profession want to help reduce maternal and child mortality. Every year, thousands of mothers and children die in pregnancy or during childbirth in Bangladesh. With the help of a newly trained midwife, the chance of survival increases dramatically. According to the World Health Organization, the planet needs nine million more nurses and midwives if it is to achieve universal health coverage by 2030.

Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder / Election volunteer Tammy Allen assists voters as they arrive at a polling station in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, on the last day of early voting ahead of the election on Tuesday, November 3.

Allen, who volunteered at the polls for the past 14 years, said that the most important issue of the 2020 election is the COVID-19 pandemic. "People are dying and losing their jobs. And families aren't able to come together like they are used to. And the division. The pandemic shouldn't be a partisan issue. Humans are humans and we should all care about one another."

Follow @natgeointhefield for more coverage of the US election.

Post description:

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @nataliekeyssar / A man became agitated and started yelling when the polls opened late in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, today. He complained, saying everyone had jobs to go to and kids at home. Eventually the constable came out to try to calm him down, which resulted in a short argument. Many voters in the line said they shared the man’s frustration.

Voters lined up before 7 a.m. on Election Day at Wilkes-Barre's Toyota SportsPlex located at 38 Coal Street, a nod to the industry that once drove this region. Most people waited quietly as the polls opened a bit late on the frigid morning, although a few voters complained of the delays and others of their original polling places being closed without warning. Wilkes-Barre is a contested city in Luzerne County, an important swing county in Pennsylvania.

Follow @natgeointhefield for more coverage of the US election.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @nataliekeyssar / Jenis Walsh, Northeast regional director for the Pennsylvania Democratic Party, sits at her desk at the office of the Democratic Party in Wilkes-Barre on November 2. “I have one day left,” she said, referring to the election. “And all we have to do is execute, execute, execute." Wilkes-Barre has been hotly contested.

Follow @natgeointhefield for more coverage of the US election.

When asked how it felt to vote for the first time, he said, "I feel like a man."

Perez, who is a college student at Marquette University, said he'd just woken up and had come to cast his ballot at 1:45 p.m. "I wanted to get here as early as possible."

The line at the polling place was largely composed of Trump supporters in an area with many Trump signs.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @nataliekeyssar / Brittany Flores poses for a portrait with Joshua Flores and her daughter Isabelle Flores in Scranton, Pennsylvania. They came to the Biden campaign headquarters in Scranton when they heard Joe Biden was there "because we figured it was important to support him,” said Brittany. “I believe everybody deserves equality no matter what race they identify as and who they love. We used to live in what they call Trump Country and I was illegally evicted for putting up a Black Lives Matter sign. I feel safer here in Scranton."

On Election Day Joe Biden made an appearance at 314 Pear Street in Scranton, where campaign workers were handing out materials for the last day of leafleting and signposting to get out the vote.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto / Kačna jama (cave) is 280 meters (over 900 feet) deep, the third longest cave in Slovenia. Although from this photograph, it could be anywhere, couldn't it?

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder / Kristan Small holds a flag in honor of her father, Korean War veteran Gordon Small, who died on May 8 after contracting COVID-19. She joined a small crowd gathered on the steps of the Michigan State Capitol, in Lansing, to call for the complete counting of presidential election votes. She said, “My father died of COVID because his home health nurse didn’t have proper PPE. But that’s not why I’m here tonight. I’m here because we have a president who has claimed to have absolute authority but hasn’t read the Constitution. We know that democracy is fragile. My father would not have stood for that. My father voted in every election. They’d damn well better count my vote.”

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @daviddoubilet / Blacktip sharks patrol the shallow reefs at sunset over the South Pass at Fakarava Atoll, a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve in French Polynesia. The productive coral reef and lagoon system here support 700+ gray reef and blacktip sharks, one of the densest populations of sharks on the planet. The smaller blacktips favor the shallows by day, and the gray reef sharks gather in distinct groups in the depths. As the sun sets they form large hunting packs that scour the reef for a meal. #Sharks For #MoreOcean follow @DavidDoubilet.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @celestesloman / This portrait of Coline Jenkins, descendent of legendary suffragist Elizabeth Cady Stanton, is from a series celebrating the centennial of women's suffrage, published in National Geographic's August issue. The year 2020 marks the anniversary of the passage of the 19th Amendment, which guarantees and protects women's constitutional right to vote.

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder / Ralph Gaines and Angelo Austin argue with a Trump supporter protesting the validity of the presidential vote count outside the TCF Center, where votes are being tallied, in Detroit, Michigan.

Austin said, "My ancestors helped to build this city. These people think I'm wrong for not wanting to support the president who is a racist and a sexist. They are out here without a mask and not social distancing because they don't care about anyone but themselves."

"The votes were counted," Gaines added. "We should all be coming together right now. We need a president who leads and who takes care of everybody. He's just causing chaos."

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @carltonward / The Florida black bear is one of my favorite species. Learning about its landscape movements from scientists inspired a team (including me) to create the Florida Wildlife Corridor project, a campaign to protect a network of public and private lands throughout Florida as connected wildlife habitat. Bears need a lot of room to roam, and their seven sub-populations throughout Florida, from Pensacola to Naples, will become increasingly cut off from one another if we don't protect wildlife corridors. To learn more, please follow me @carltonward and @pathofthepanther, a #LastWildPlaces partnership with @insidenatgeo working to inspire protection of the Florida Wildlife Corridor. @FL_WildCorridor #Florida #bear #KeepFLWild

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @katieorlinsky / At a blueberry farm in May’s Landing, New Jersey, farmworkers and their children are tested for COVID-19 at a pop-up run by the Southern Jersey Family Medical Centers, an organization that has done most of the testing at area blueberry farms. Every year an estimated 6,000 migrant farmworkers arrive at blueberry farms in South Jersey for the short and intense eight-week summer harvest. Workers often bring their children with them and normally these children can attend all-day, government-sponsored programs that provide free busing, three meals, academic instruction, summer camp, and English classes. This year, programs were cancelled because of the pandemic. Check out @natgeo’s link in bio for more on this story, created with the support of the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @nataliekeyssar / On Thursday evening, dueling protests continued in front of the PA Convention Center where the state’s votes are being counted. On one side of Arch Street, protesters supported the continuation of the vote count. Across the street, a group of Trump supporters demanded the count be stopped.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @tamaramerino_photography / Coober Pedy is an unconventional town in the Australian Outback where most of the population lives in underground houses called dugouts. Personal and social life takes place under the desolate and burning Simpsons Desert. Since 1915 Coober Pedy has been exploited for the extraction of opal, a precious stone, and is also the largest opal mining area in the world, with more than 70 mining fields. Goran Dakovic, a Yugoslavian miner, searches for any trace of opal on the wall. He has found a good amount of opal while working on this mine by himself for over three years.

This photo is part of my series Underland, which documents communities living underground or in caves houses around the world. Follow me on @tamaramerino_photography for more.
#caves #undergroundhouse #underland

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @bertiegregory / How many fish can a puffin carry in its beak? Guess below in the comments! This Atlantic puffin has a bill packed full of sand eels (but the record is many more). Puffins breed on land but fish at sea, so being able to carry multiple prey at once is key to efficiently raising a puffling (a puffin chick). The busy summer breeding colonies have now emptied out and the puffins will spend the rest of the year at sea. Next spring, the adults will return to land to start the whole process again. Meanwhile, the pufflings will stay at sea for 3-5 years before returning to land to raise their own chicks. Follow @bertiegregory for more wildlife adventures! #puffin #britishwildlife #cute #fishing #wildlifephotography

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @babaktafreshi / Swipe to see the entire view. The longest canyon on Earth, at the Arizona-Utah border, offers dramatic scenes when you catch the right time and light. This super wide-angle view from west to east shows the yellow-red light of early twilight, just a few minutes after sunset, illuminating the canyon on the right (east), and the blue-purple color of the rising Earth shadow in the sky, right above an extinct volcano near the canyon rim. This atmospheric phenomenon happens after each sunset and before every sunrise, but often is missed by most people, not knowing what they're looking at. It's the shadow that Earth itself casts onto its atmosphere and into outer space, toward the point opposite the sun. It's prominent in a clear sky above an open horizon, especially at high altitudes. Explore more from dusk to dawn @babaktrafreshi.
#earth #grandcanyon #twilight

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @jasperdoest / Conservation mascot Flamingo Bob, as he's known, is seen in one the plantation mansions on Curaçao, a reminder of the island's colonial past. Curaçao was conquered by the Netherlands in the 17th century at a time when—and well into the 19th century—the region was dominated by slavery. The colonies served as military bases, trading posts, and plantations. ⠀
The relationship between the Netherlands and the Caribbean colonies changed in the second half of the 20th century, as residents became dissatisfied with the predominance of Dutch businesses in the economy of Curaçao while many people still lived in poverty. Eventually each island decided that a separate relationship with the Netherlands would be better. In October 2010 the Netherlands Antilles officially ceased to exist and Curaçao became an independent constituent country within the Kingdom of the Netherlands. This month marks 10 years of independence, yet the balance of this new status and the retention of the old connections still results in a complex relationship. ⠀
⠀
Since my father was born on Curaçao, the story of Flamingo Bob is also a tribute to my own history. It is also a celebration of something positive that transcends this complex history. The story of Flamingo Bob is a reminder that individual actions, driven by love and empathy, can have an enormous impact on the world around us—something this world needs, more than ever. Follow @jasperdoest to learn more about Flamingo Bob. #flamingobob #meetbob #flamingo #birdrescue #curacao

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown / Before we moved to our home in Los Angeles, my partner had a tattoo of nasturtium flowers on her forearm. After our move, hundreds of nasturtium flowers of all sizes formed a perimeter around our house during spring. Our daughter, Poppy, is named after the California state flower. The spring after she was born, we found ourselves once again surrounded by beautiful nasturtiums. Follow me @michaelchristopherbrown for more human stories from around the world.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @joelsartore / Gorillas like Lamydoc @gladysporterzoo share 98.3% of their genetic code with us, making them one of our closest relatives. While western lowland gorillas are the most numerous of all gorilla species, they are still listed as critically endangered. The spread of Ebola as well as the poaching of gorillas for bushmeat and their capture for the pet trade have all contributed to the decline of this great ape. As human populations continue to grow, competition for resources between humans and gorillas intensifies, which can result in heightened conflict. However, communities living near gorillas see ecotourism as a reason to protect the species and its habitat, as increased tourism creates jobs for people in surrounding villages and supports the local economy. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk #savetogether

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Pete McBride @pedromcbride / I love describing the auditory notes behind the pixels I’ve chased for years—those subtle sounds like the "applause of rain on rock," or the orchestra of dripping, created by melting ice in the Antarctic Peninsula, a place that faces some of the highest temperature increases on the planet and has lost an average of 163 billion tons of ice each year since 2002. For more on silence and natural sounds, head to @pedromcbride. #antarctica #seeingsilence #quiet #silence #petemcbride

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @johnstanmeyer / The hands of Resham Singh, a 59-year-old carpenter in Punjab, are gnarled from arthritis. Doctors say it may have been caused by exposure to water tainted by fertilizers and pesticides. Heavy use of chemicals in the 1960s to late 1970s brought India out of famine and into its green revolution, but Singh’s village, Mari Mustafa, has high cancer rates. This image is from my latest story, in the August issue, "Water Everywhere, and Nowhere," now on newsstands worldwide. @outofedenwalk #walkingindia #edenwalk #india #marimustafa #punjab

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @nataliekeyssar / Cooper Sherwin and Joan Taylor, who both canvassed for Biden in Pennsylvania, kiss while Cooper holds his framed Declaration of Independence. Around midday on November 7, the Associated Press and several news networks reported that Joe Biden won the state of Pennsylvania, making him the next president of the United States. After a fraught week for Philadelphia, Biden supporters came to Independence Hall, where the Constitution and Declaration of Independence were created, to celebrate.
Follow @natgeointhefield for more coverage of the US election.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @amivitale / Meet Molly, my trusty companion in Montana's Centennial Valley. Here, people seem to measure worth by how comfortable you are around animals and they around you. I have seen young toddlers on horseback nestled between mother and mane. By two, they are nuzzling calves. Children learn to throw a rope before they can talk. It's a place where people are shaped by the land and they in turn help shape the land. I hope we can all use this moment to reflect and reimagine a different way forward, where we focus on building a universal trust and we reforge vital connections to each other, in our communities, and with the earth. Follow @amivitale for more stories about connections between humanity and nature. @nature_org @centennialvalleyassociation @thephotosociety #bigskycountry #outwest #horses #montana #conservation

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder / Trump supporter Kevin Skinner (right) and a Black Lives Matter member who gave his name as Marvin F. hug on the steps of the Michigan State Capitol in Lansing. The two men briefly embraced during arguments between Trump supporters protesting the results of the election and counter-protesters calling for respect for the results.
Follow @natgeointhefield for more coverage of the US election.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Karla Gachet @kchete77 / Jose Chavez gets ready in the morning at his home in Bakersfield, California. Jose's wife, Martha, gave birth a week prior to this photo. She wakes up with Jose at 4:30 a.m. to make his lunch for work. Jose is a "mayordomo," organizing a group of 25 men to prune cherry trees. He has been working in the fields for 20 years. He was a worker himself for 10 years before becoming a mayordomo, so he says he's very conscientious about giving people breaks and having ice water available all day long. According to law, when the temperature reaches 80°F (about 26°C) there should be shade where the workers can take breaks. They should be allowed to take a paid, five-minute (or as long as needed) break if they start feeling bad. When the temperature reaches 95°F (35°C), they should automatically be given a 10-minute break, and there should be a plan on how to proceed in case of an emergency. #HEAT #migrantfarmworkers #CentralValley

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner / The Florida burrowing owl is a special kind of force, and the Marco Island community is the species’ force field. The epitome of perseverance, this owl digs its burrows in million-dollar lawns and raises its chicks to adulthood while navigating a concrete landscape of humans, trash, dogs, cats, and cars—and it even steals lace panties off clothing lines to decorate its home during mating season. This is a species that has changed its normal behavior to live among the humans who have redefined its home—and on Marco Island, a small group of humans are doing their best to protect it. Owl Watch, a community volunteer organization that monitors burrows on Marco Island, has helped create laws to protect the owls and also begun a ‘starter burrow’ project. If you're a homeowner and you'd like owls to burrow in your yard, @audubonsociety’s Owl Watch team will dig starter burrows in your lawn to entice the owls to choose you! For more wildlife stories follow @kaigner! #burrowingowl #urbanwildlife #owls

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Anastasia Taylor-Lind @anastasiatl / Ghazanchetsots cathedral in Shushi, Nagorno-Karabakh, was shelled on October 8. After more than 20 years of relative calm, fighting between Azeri and Armenian forces has been escalating since September 27, causing casualties and inflicting suffering on all sides. I worked in the region in 2011, when I photographed Father Andreas marrying Ara Avagimyan and Elita Khachaturyan at the cathedral. #nagornokarabakh.

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more info.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @noralorek / On the shore of Lake Victoria, a two-hour drive from Uganda's capital, Kampala, the roads turn into piers and bridges that take you to Lunkulu island, the home of Bayimba Festival. The festival of arts launched in 2008 in central Kampala, but two years ago Bayimba got its own space, free from the limits of the city.

I've documented festivals all over the world for 12 years, and it’s been wonderful to see how much these cultural events and all of us have in common, no matter if on an island near the equator or at a farm near my home in Sweden. This year COVID-19 put all of it on hold—and the lack of art reminds us more than ever how much we need it.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @lucalocatelliphoto / Breeding chambers buzz with black soldier flies at Entocycle, in London, a start-up developing technologies to farm insects for industrial protein production—a more sustainable alternative to meat, growing them on brewery and coffee waste. The land and water required to farm insects is just a fraction of that for poultry or cattle. Harvesting larvae fed on food waste could be an even more sustainable incentive to insect protein production.

Food waste is a big issue covered in my latest cover story for National Geographic, called on the "End of Trash," on circular economy solutions. By designing waste out of the production system, circularity aims to keep resources and materials in use.
Scientists claim we only have a few years to halt and reverse our overconsumption, emissions, and a wasteful attitude in order to save our changing climate, the natural habitat, and, ultimately, ourselves.

A circular economy is one solution, but the truth is there isn't one single solution. Yet each of us can make a difference by being mindful of our actions and staying informed. Throughout my career I have used photography to tell stories about how we are learning new ways to live on Earth. Please follow me @lucalocatelliphoto to learn how we can make a difference.
#environment #circulareconomy #insects #London #lucalocatelliphoto

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @irablockphoto / A stray dog sits in as Buddhist monks chant in a temple in Luangprabang, Laos. It is common to see dogs and cats around monasteries, where they are cared for and fed—as Buddha required followers to care for all living beings. In earlier times, dogs had another function at Buddhist monasteries: the Lhasa Apso breed was used to alert monks to any intruders. #luangprabang #monks #buddhism #laos #irablock

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @paoloverzone / Longyearbyen, Svalbard, Norway. This is from a day out to measure record ice loss on the Foxfonna glacier with Andy Hodson, glaciologist at @unisvalbard. Hodson says the ice cap suffered from the combination of the lowest snow accumulation we've observed (a consequence of a cold, dry winter), followed by the highest observed summer melt (not surprising, given the record temperatures this July). #svalbard #norway #foxfonna #glacier #glaciologist
Follow @paoloverzone for more photos and stories.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @ismailferdous / Ali, an immigrant from Pakistan who lives on Long Island, came to Times Square with his family to celebrate the winners of the presidential election on November 7. Kamala Harris is the first female, first South Asian American, and first person of color to be elected vice president of the United States. Her mother, Shyamala Gopalan Harris, was an immigrant from India. Last night Vice President-elect Harris said, "To the children of our country, regardless of your gender, our country has sent you a clear message: Dream with ambition, lead with conviction, and see yourselves in a way that others may not, simply because they’ve never seen it before, but know that we will applaud you every step of the way."

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @beverlyjoubert / It’s one of the most mesmerizing sounds of the African wild. For the lion, an aural alert shores up the boundaries of territory, a resonating message for kin and foe. For us, a reminder of things untamed, of the might in nature’s beauty. It’s also a sound that’s unique and personal–each roar a distinct vocal signature that companions and neighbors can recognize. To stand by and listen as these iconic cats fall silent is not an option. It’s why we’ve dedicated our lives to ensuring their roars will be heard across Africa for generations to come. #bigcats #lions #bigcatconservation

Post description:
Photo by @paoloverzone / Fluorescing a ghostly blue, a stained chicken embryo in Yale paleontologist Bhart-Anjan Bhullar's lab is in line to be examined under a microscope. By tracking how genes orchestrate the patterns of animals’ growing bodies, Bhullar can see the nuts and bolts of development, improving our understanding of dinosaurs and their modern descendants.

Follow @paoloverzone for more photos and stories.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @dina_litovsky / Most people don’t associate the Amish and Mennonites with leisure, but every winter Amish and Mennonite families from all around the U.S. flock to Pinecraft, a community in Sarasota, Florida, for vacation. The small neighborhood, encompassing about 10 blocks, becomes a busy snowbird capital where different Anabaptist denominations escape the winter and mingle among each other. The usual rules are a bit looser—a blind eye is turned to the use of cell phones, cameras, and bicycles while recreational activities are encouraged. For more images, follow me @dina_litovsky.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Engineers work on the ATLAS detector in this time-lapse from science photographer @babaktafreshi. With a weight similar to the Eiffel Tower, this 7,000-ton, 46-meter long cylinder sits in a cavern 100 meters (yards) below ground, as part of the Large Hadron Collider at the CERN lab in Switzerland. This international effort to accelerate particles and observe their collisions may change our understanding of matter—and the history of the universe. Music by tonelabs.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @erintrieb / On Election Day I set up a portrait studio outside a polling station in Houston, Texas, where I asked voters if I could photograph them. It was a heart-warming experience to hear in their own words—and some were first-time voters—what it means to exercise their 15th Amendment right.

Batrice Thomas stands with her son Brandon Allen Jr., 6, outside the NRG polling station in Houston, on November 3. In Batrice’s words: “It took us so long to actually get to vote as women, period. I want my kids to see that we’re trying to make a change and for especially my daughter to see that girls can do the same things that guys do.” For more human stories from around the world follow @erintrieb.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photos by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto / From Grandma's Recipes project. Bisrat Melake, 60, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, demonstrated a favorite meal. Ingredients: 1 savoy cabbage, 10 sweet green chillies, 25 string beans, red chili powder, 4 onions, oil, salt, pepper, cauliflower leaves, a plate of mitin shuro (yellow dried-pea powder), a plate of split peas, yeast, and teff flour.

You'll need to cook ingredients separately, and preparation takes three days. For injera (flatbread): Mix one kilo of teff flour and one spoon of yeast with water until you obtain a smooth and dense dough. Let it ferment for three days; the dough will soften. Add water until it becomes cream-like. Use it in the same way as when you make crepes. / Curry: Stir-fry three chopped onions and 10 chopped chillies in oil for a few minutes. Add three cups of water and cook for about 10 minutes. Then add the split peas and the plate of mitin shuro. Mix well, cover and cook on low heat for about 30 minutes. / Cauliflower leaves: Boil in water. Drain, chop, and fry them with oil, onion, and salt. / Liquid curry (the small orange spots in the photo): Fry lightly half an onion and a pinch of hot chili powder in some oil. Add 200 grams of mitin shuro and two cups of water. Cook for 20 minutes. / String beans and savoy salad: Slice the savoy into strips and chop the beans. Boil together. Drain and saute with oil and chili for about 10 minutes. Serve.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @maggiesteber / A decal of President-elect Joe Biden adorns a car in downtown Miami, Florida, on Saturday, as hundreds of residents gathered in the streets to celebrate the news that Biden had reached the number of electoral college votes he needed to beat President Donald Trump in the election. Although President Trump carried the state of Florida, voters came out in support of Biden in one of the largest early-voter turnouts in the state's history.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @mattiasklumofficial / Vamizi, off the coast of Mozambique, is home to some of the world’s oldest and most pristine coral reefs—a virtual wonderland of biodiversity. The Southern Equatorial Current meets the African continent here, bringing with it warm waters and an upwelling of rich nutrients. Sheltered by the coral reefs, the area is an undersea nursery, a critical breeding and birthing ground for hundreds of species. Please go to @mattiasklumofficial for more images and films from remarkable and vulnerable places like Vamizi. #saveourseas #saveouroceans #protectbiodiversity #privilege #livingthedream

The two flamingos in the back each had a wing amputated and similarly wouldn't survive in the wild, so they hang out with Bob in their private saltwater pool—flamingos normally hang out in family groups. Follow @jasperdoest to learn more about Flamingo Bob. #flamingobob #meetbob #flamingo #birdrescue #poolflamingo

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Prasenjeet Yadav @prasen.yadav / Forest officials from India's Himachal Pradesh state tend to an injured snow leopard cub. The one-year-old male had been chased by feral dogs and got separated from his mother. Domestic dog populations have increased in the Himalaya with the presence of humans, and many of them have now become feral. Feral dogs are a direct threat to the wild herbivores and direct competition for carnivores such as the snow leopard. After this snow leopard got chased, he took refuge in one of the defense camps in the mountains and was later rescued. Vets tended to the cub's wounds and tried their best to save it, but unfortunately, the animal died two days later. Follow me @prasen.yadav for more photos from India.
#India #Himalayas #snowleopard

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen / Meteora, a UNESCO World Heritage site in central Greece, is best known for its clifftop monasteries. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic #muhammedmuheisen #Meteora #Greece

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by @dina_litovsky / When Joe Biden was announced as President-elect on November 7, I went out to capture the mood on the streets of New York City. The whole city seemed to be intoxicated by the victory, full of happy noise—cars honking, people singing and laughing. I witnessed the pent-up frustration of the past four years explode into a wave of joyful optimism. For more images, follow me @dina_litovsky.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by George Steinmetz @geosteinmetz / On the high, dry plains of Qinghai Province in northwestern China, one of the country’s fastest growing solar-power facilities spreads amid desert sands. The hundreds of photovoltaic panels in the Golmud Solar Park track the sun’s location through the day to glean the most energy. An enormous expansion of panel arrays is under way in the region, with some estimates suggesting that by 2030 the combined generation capacity when the sun is shining could be akin to that from five large coal or nuclear plants. At present, there is no way to store the energy for nighttime use. To view more of our world from above, follow @geosteinmetz.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman / It's currently fall migration season for monarch butterflies, some of whom are traveling up to 3,000 miles south to overwinter in the southern United States and Mexico. The trip is fraught, with dangers ranging from storms to pesticides to deforestation to climate change. The 2019-2020 season saw a 53 percent decrease in the number of monarchs that made it to one particular protected forest in Mexico—an alarming trend for the future of this important pollinator. Travel safe, friends!

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @tasneemalsultan / Most Arab, African, and Indian cultures celebrate weddings with a henna ceremony as part of the event. It's interesting to see how we share a similar fashion in fabrics and heavy traditional gold to decorate the bride.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @stephenwilkes / In November 2019 I traveled to the Canadian Arctic to capture a "Day To Night" image of the polar bears in Churchill, as they began their journey across a frozen Hudson Bay. We photographed from a tundra buggy over the course of 36 hours in extreme cold conditions. Fortunately, I was able to photograph through a window, with just the front of my lens exposed.

In the Day to Night series, epic landscapes are portrayed from a fixed camera angle, capturing fleeting moments of humanity and nature as light passes in front of the lens over the course of a full day. A select group of these images are blended into a single composite.

This is one of the most challenging, Day to Night photographs I have created. Expeditions can sometimes last for days without seeing a polar bear, as the bears are very adept at camouflaging themselves against the snow. Plus, once the bay freezes, the bears immediately begin to cross it in search of food. We were fortunate to catch the final moments of the freeze and see the few bears remaining, making their way across. The number of bears we saw was much less than in previous years, and the data is now correlating to the fact that warmer air and the rise in water temperature mean that less ice is being created—a combination with a direct impact on the survival of this species.

I'm excited to announce that with the generous support of @insidenatgeo and in collaboration with @cangeo I will be documenting endangered species and habitats in Canada over the next few years. So stay tuned! To see more from my travels near and far, follow me @stephenwilkes. #insidenatgeo #cangeo #daytonight

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman / A large chunk of ice calves from the Esmarkbreen Glacier in Svalbard's Ymerbukta Bay. This piece was probably roughly the size of two double-decker buses. Runoff from melting glaciers contributes to sea level rise, which impacts coastal communities through flooding and triggering erosion and more intense storms. Follow me at @dzalcman for more stories from the Arctic.
