Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @dina_litovsky / I spend my nights walking around New York City, photographing a metropolis slowly returning to life after months of quarantine. I look for streetlights that offer sanctuary, illuminating lonely passersby shuffling in and out of darkness. This was photographed in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. For more images of NYC, follow me @dina_litovsky.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @mattiasklumofficial / In the world of the blue-footed booby, bluer is better. The male courts the female by trotting around with excessive strides. Then they walk around each other for hours, showing off their feet in a slow ballet. Please follow @mattiasklumofficial for more images from remarkable and vulnerable places around the world. I took this photograph on assignment for @natgeo in the Galapagos, Ecuador. #bluefootedbooby #protectbiodivetsity #Galapagos

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photos by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen / Since last week, I have been roaming the empty streets of Athens and some suburbs to document the current lockdown in Greece. On Thursday, November 5, Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis announced a lockdown starting on Saturday, November 7, for three weeks, with the aim to contain the spread of the coronavirus. Few days after, a curfew from 9 p.m. to 5 a.m. was imposed.

Seen in this carousel: empty Monastiraki Square; a closed retail shop; a man reading the newspaper; shuttered restaurants in the Plaka District; Margi above her closed souvenir shop in the Plaka District; an empty street downtown; and finally Syntagma Square. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #muhammedmuheisen #Greece #Athens #StaySafe

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @sarahyltonphoto / Wade Sikorski, 64, a farmer from Baker, Montana, displays corn from his crop that was destroyed by a hail storm. "It was the worst hail storm of my life," he said. Extreme weather events have become more common in the region, according to Sikorski, and the rate of temperature rise in Montana is higher than the rest of the nation. Sikorski is active in opposing extraction projects, including the Keystone XL pipeline. "The thing that I worry about most is the impact it will have on global warming, and how it will affect extreme weather events...basically it comes down to food or oil," he said. For more stories, follow me @sarahyltonphoto. #Montana #climatechange #globalwarming

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Joseph feeds Meibai at Reteti Elephant Sanctuary in northern Kenya, captured by @amivitale. @r.e.s.c.u.e is the first ever community-owned elephant sanctuary in Africa. What’s happening at @r.e.s.c.u.e is nothing less than the beginnings of a transformation, not only in the way humans relate to wild animals but also how we relate to one another. Follow @amivitale and @r.e.s.c.u.e to learn more, including how to help. @conservationorg @kenyawildlifeservice @sandiegozoo @tusk_org @thephotosociety #protectelephants #elephants #stoppoaching #kenya

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @lucalocatelliphoto / A 3D scan of mycelium biomaterial is made at Ecovative Design in Green Island, New York, which is researching sustainable alternatives to plastic packaging—by using mushroom technology.

This novel class of renewable biomaterial may replace petroleum-based products that take many years to decompose, if ever. The search for new materials is part of my March cover story for National Geographic magazine on the circular economy. By designing waste out of the production system, circularity aims to keep resources and materials in use while regenerating natural systems.

Scientists say we only have a few years to halt and reverse our overconsumption, our emissions, and our wasteful attitude in order to save our changing climate, the natural habitats, and, ultimately, ourselves.

While the circular economy is a promising solution, it is only one of the tools that may help. The truth is there isn't one single solution, yet each one of us can make a difference by being more intentional in our actions and staying informed. Follow me @lucalocatelliphoto to learn more.
#environment #circulareconomy #mushroom #plastic #lucalocatelliphoto

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photos by Stephen Alvarez @salvarezphoto / A bull elk bugles in the Cataloochee Valley of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Elk call to each other. In this case, the bull is calling to the cows in his group to keep them together—and away from
competing males.

On this beautiful morning in mid-October, a hundred or more people braved the narrow, winding dirt road that leads into the valley to the herd. Great herds of elk used to be common in the eastern United States, but since the mid-1800s, their only remnants were names: Elkmont, Banner Elk, the Elk River— where I live in Tennessee.

Elk are enormous; a bull can weigh over 700 pounds (300 kg). It is hard to appreciate how vast a project reintroducing a huge animal into its original habitat is. Bringing elk back to
the Smoky Mountains National Park took 10 years of study across the federal, state, and local levels, culminating in 2001, when the first 25 animals were reintroduced. Today the herd has grown to almost 200.

Seeing and hearing them is a visceral experience. People flock to this part of the park just for a glimpse of these magnificent animals. Follow me, @salvarezphoto for more images from around the world.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @timlaman / Scarlet Ibises fly past the moon. One thing the pandemic has done is given me time to work with my archive to look for those unpublished gems that I might use in a book or other project. This is a favorite image from a 2011 shoot in the Orinoco River Delta, Venezuela. Swipe to see the full image. See more of my treasures from my explorations of nature around the world @TimLaman.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @johnstanmeyer / In a crowded restaurant filled only with men, smoke from a wood-burning stove swirls on the ceiling. This image was taken in Bhagalpur, located on the banks of the Ganges River in the state of Bihar, India, and is from my latest story in @natgeo magazine, "Water Everywhere, and Nowhere," in the August issue, now on newsstands worldwide. @outofedenwalk #walkingindia #edenwalk #india #bhagalpur #bihar

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @jasperdoest / I remember the scene as if it happened today: First, a head peeks through a doorway and soon the rest of the figure follows, apparently unbothered by my presence. I smile and rouse myself from sleep, still fighting jet lag. I search for my camera, only to find the battery dead. Why now!? Clearly I wasn’t prepared for this. I stare at the flamingo in front of me, and before I know it he’s on his way out again. Obviously I’m not as interesting to him as he is to me. I can’t help thinking, nonody is going to believe this. Luckily I would have many more chances to capture this flamingo, a rescue animal that lives with my cousin, a veterinarian, in Curacao. Follow @jasperdoest to learn more about Flamingo Bob. #flamingobob #meetbob #flamingo #birdrescue #curacao

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by Michael Yamashita @yamashitaphoto / Lost in fog, Kyushu, Japan: a view from above the clouds in Aso-Kuju National Park. Centered around several active volcanos and hot springs, Aso is often called Earth's volcanic theater. #AsoKujuNationalpark #Kyushu #Japan

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Practice makes perfect. A male Raggiana bird of paradise practices his dance moves in the rainforest of New Guinea, even though no female is present. Birds of paradise are iconic species in the New Guinea region (parts of Indonesia and PNG), the largest intact rainforest region in Asia-Pacific and critical for global conservation. You’ll find a longer video of this species @TimLaman – do check it out. And learn more at @BirdsofParadiseProject. #RaggianaBirdofparadise #Birdsofparadise #PNG #PapuaNewGuinea #NewGuinea

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photos by @florianschulzvisuals / The outgoing Trump Administration is moving to complete a last-minute oil lease sale in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, as the Interior Department set a process in motion to approve a new seismic survey of nearly half a million acres of the refuge's coastal plain.

The proposed survey involves hundreds of miles of seismic exploration "trails" that would result from 90,000-pound seismic vehicles crisscrossing the fragile tundra. It would scar the landscape and threaten denning polar bears. Such a proposal typically requires a lengthy environmental review, but the administration appears poised to fast-track the process in order to get seismic testing under way before the Biden Administration takes over. Please follow me @florianschulzvisuals for more images of the last great wild places we need to protect for future generations! #ProtectTheArctic

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @babaktafreshi / I've lived for several years on Boston's North Shore, and this was one of the most stunning scenes I've experienced. A storm cloud moved across the ocean, above the island of Nahant. Behind me, the sun had already set, but the last rays were shining on the clouds like a red spotlight. Explore more from dusk to dawn @babaktafreshi. #fineart #earth #ocean #boston

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown / Outside a Catholic school for boys, located in Minova, Democratic Republic of the Congo, where roughly half the population is Catholic. Described by Michael G Schatzberg as the "only truly national institution apart from the state,” Catholic schools have educated over 60 percent of the nation's primary school students and more than 40 percent of its secondary students. The church owns and manages an extensive network of hospitals, schools, and clinics, as well as many diocesan economic enterprises, including farms, ranches, stores, and artisan shops. Follow @michaelchristopherbrown for more human stories from around the world.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by George Steinmetz @geosteinmetz / Africa has lost one of its giants to COVID-19. This is Jerry Rawlings, who was a flight lieutenant in the Ghana's air force—and four-time president of the country—when he gave me an afternoon on the parapet outside his office at Osu Castle, in June 1985. I was on my first international assignment, and I was thrown in the jail for a week in neighboring Burkina Faso for taking pictures of smugglers crossing the Ghanian border. Rawlings got word of my predicament and personally intervened to have me released. A revolutionary leader who led his country out of a post-colonial crisis, Rawlings was also an expert military jet and helicopter pilot. Leading Ghana was a tenuous position in 1985, and somewhat hidden in this picture was a small pistol he kept in his left boot. To see more from my travels in Africa and beyond, follow @geosteinmetz.

Editor’s Note: The caption was updated with a cause of death.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @erintrieb / One year ago, in November 2019, thousands of Iraqis organized to protest Iraq’s sectarian political system and government corruption. For several months Iraqi youth successfully occupied central Baghdad, where hundreds of protestors were killed and thousands injured, prompting Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi to resign. COVID-19 brought Iraq’s protests to a halt, with the rise of curfews and social distancing, but the impact of the protests continues to ripple through and in some cases upend the status quo. Here protestors take cover behind a homemade barricade after Iraqi security forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets. For more human stories from around the world follow @erintrieb.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photos by David Chancellor @chancellordavid / A white male giraffe at the Ishaqbini community conservancy in Kenya. Initially rangers had spotted three giraffes here. These are not albino but exhibit an extremely rare genetic trait called leucism. This inhibits skin cells from producing pigment but allows other organs such as eyes to be dark colored. Albinism, a congenital condition, inhibits the body from producing pigment in all organs, and animals with this condition often have pink eyes. In March a female and her calf were slaughtered by poachers, leaving only this male.

As a result, on Sunday, at the request of the community at Ishaqbini, a combined operation of @nrt_kenya and @kenyawildlifeservice placed a global positioning satellite unit on one of the ossicones (horn) of the surviving sub-adult male giraffe. It will allow rangers to monitor its movement, and in doing so keep this extraordinarily unique, gentle creature safer from poachers. Safeguarding wildlife is enormously complex, as is the whole conversation about intervention and the collaring of wildlife. In this case, I believe that sadly this is our best chance at helping to protect this special animal. I’ve flown over him a few times and marveled from afar at nature’s magnificence. The fact that there were three and now only one is way past presenting a metaphor for man’s relationship with nature. It’s simply evil. To see more follow me @chancellordavid. @nrt_kenya

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @celestesloman / This is a portrait of KC, photographed in the Great Salt Pond on Block Island. The island is a very special place that never ceases to inspire. KC is a seasonal worker who spends summers on the island. Located off the coast of Rhode Island, Block Island has a small population that increases drastically in the summer months, with an influx of tourists and seasonal workers. With no hospital on the island and an aging year-round population, islanders have been vigilant about preventing an outbreak of COVID-19.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / If you’ve ever wondered why plants change color in the autumn, here’s a brief explanation: As the days get shorter, leaves stop producing chlorophyll, a pigment triggered by sunlight that helps the leaf absorb energy through photosynthesis. Once chlorophyll production ceases, the green color fades and the pigment xanthophyll begins to show—typically in the yellow, orange, and red spectrum. These colors are a clear signal that the flora is moving into winter hibernation. This carousel was photographed in a 30-foot radius in South Bend, Indiana. To see more fall photos, please visit @ladzinski.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by @carltonward / These drone views show Interstate 75 cutting through the western Everglades—and the core of Florida panther habitat. Florida Panther National Wildlife Refuge is on the left and Picayune Strand State Forest on the right. The second photo shows a wildlife underpass, combined with high fences along the road to funnel wildlife to cross safely beneath the highway. Panthers and other large animals are rarely killed on the fenced segments of I-75. But few roads have fencing and underpasses, leaving vehicle strikes as the leading recorded cause of death for Florida panthers—more than 30 per year. For photos of some of the wildlife crossing beneath the road, see @carltonward and @pathofthepanther. #LastWildPlaces @fl_wildcorridor @my_Fdot @usfws. For the @PathofthePanther Last Wild Places partnership with @InsideNatgeo.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by @paolowoods / Keith Jarrett, one of the world’s most acclaimed musicians, recently announced that due to health issues he may never preform live again. He's particularly famous for his improvisation abilities, and the Köln Concert—piano improvisations performed in Cologne, Germany—remains the best selling solo album in jazz history. Jarrett is famously camera shy, but I managed to photograph him at the piano in his studio, adjacent to his farmhouse in Oxford, New Jersey, for a 2016 National Geographic story on what makes a genius.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @stevewinterphoto / At a VIP event an attendee looks at two tigers in their traveling cages before a show. There are only 3,900 tigers left in the wild! We need to fight for the right of tigers to live peacefully and without being killed for the traditional medicine market, tiger bone wine, tiger skin furniture, and other trade.

Our animal family is so much like us—they find mates, have kids, feed themselves and their families. If we can find a way to believe that they think, feel, and have emotions, maybe we can treat them better—and ensure their future on this planet.

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @ismailferdous / A herd of bison, as seen in Hot Springs State Park, Thermopolis, Wyoming. For more pictures follow @ismailferdous.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @joelsartore / The California condor, like this one @phoenixzoo, is one of the largest flying birds in the world. Thousands of years ago, California condors lived in many parts of North America, but as settlers moved west, they disturbed the condors by hunting them, poisoning them, collecting their eggs, and reducing the size of prey populations. Eventually, condors could no longer survive in most places, and by the late 1900s those that remained in the wild were limited to the mountainous parts of southern California. Thankfully, intensive conservation and breeding efforts have brought the condor back from the brink of extinction, with over 450 birds (both wild and captive) thriving today. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk #savetogether

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag / Portrait of a dancer before celebrating the snowfall. I took this picture last year, on August 6, the date on which Bolivia celebrates independence from the Spanish colonization. In Ushuaia, Argentina, there is a big Bolivian community that in spite of the distance (geographic and climatic) keeps its traditions alive. Follow me at @lujanag to learn more about my life and work in the southern island of Tierra del Fuego.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @irablockphoto / Barbary sheep run through a wildlife reserve on Sir Bani Yas island in the United Arab Emirates. Once deserted, Sir Bani Yas was restored into a sanctuary for endangered animals. The island has over 2.5 million trees, planted by hand, and a pipeline irrigation system that extends over 73,000 miles (117,000 km). Barbary sheep are native to North Africa and are currently a threatened species. Follow @irablockphoto for more travel stories. #UAE #barbarysheep #sirbaniyasisland #irablock

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Juan Arredondo @juanarre / Bocas de Barbacoas, Antioquia, Colombia. The marshland of Barbacoas contains great natural diversity and is in the process of becoming a sanctuary. It's been under threat by cattle farms, and local fisherman have seen a decline in the fish that travel from the marshland upstream along the Magdalena River, the principal river of Colombia. Follow @juanarre for more stories.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @tasneemalsultan / Rijal Almaa is a village in Saudi Arabia's Asir region, located along an ancient natural passage that linked Yemen, Mecca, Medina, and the Levant. Once a center of trade, the village has around 60 multi-story buildings made of stone, clay, and wood.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by George Steinmetz @geosteinmetz / Some 800 years ago the Ethiopian King Lalibela had a divine vision to carve a new Jerusalem from the volcanic stone underneath his place of birth. Monolithic churches like Bet Giorgis in Lalibela are now one of the biggest tourist draws in the country. Due to the pandemic, I might have been the only foreigner in town during my visit, with the hymns of the faithful echoing upward from the chapel below. To explore more of our world from above, follow @geosteinmetz.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @stephenwilkes / Took a drive and started a new series called Autumn Drive-by. These are single-frame captures in-camera as we were driving up the Taconic Parkway in New York. I’ll be sharing a number of images from this series, celebrating the lovely fall on the East Coast. To see more from my travels near and far follow me @stephenwilkes . #fall #foliage #impressionism

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman / On Sunday night, news broke that the Cleveland Indians will be changing their name. In 2018, I photographed lifelong Cleveland resident Jim Stamper with some of his massive collection of Chief Wahoo memorabilia—the team logo that has since been retired.

Jim, 66, has been a loyal Indians fan since 1959. He's become a recognizable personality around the ballpark, as he regularly appears at games with larger-than-life cutouts of Chief Wahoo. He, like countless other fans, has continued to appear in Wahoo gear at games in spite of the logo's official retirement in 2018.

Both Wahoo and the team's name have been heavily criticized by Native American activists and their allies for enabling racist caricatures of Indigenous people and culture. The Indians are the second sports franchise in 2020—after the Washington Football Team—to announce a change in their name from one that invokes Native culture.

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Pete McBride @pedromcbride / The Layap people of northern Bhutan live above 12,000 feet (4,000 m), where their remote village, Laya, is home to yaks and horses but historically not motorized vehicles. When I walked to Laya on assignment for @natgeo, it took 28 days to get there. In recent years, the government has constructed a road connecting Laya to nearby towns, which has shortened the walking distance over difficult terrain for the Layap to stock up on goods for the winter. Layap women traditionally wear woven hats like the one pictured here, but dwindling weavers have led to concerns over their decline. I marveled at this place's rich tapestry of traditions, and I hope they continue. For more from Bhutan and other wild places, follow @pedromcbride. #bhutan #portrait #mountains #culture

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner / The waters of the Amazon rainforest are filled with wonder and magic, and the longer you take to explore the environment, the more you begin to see. Alongside my boat in the backwaters of Yasuni National Park in Ecuador, this black caiman quietly watched us as we watched it. The two horseflies seemed to pose as blue mascara. For more images of wildlife and stories of the intersections of humans and nature, follow @kaigner. #ecuador #amazon #yasuni #caiman #reptile

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @paolowoods / The Ti-Chinwa (Little Chinese) gang, photographed in a shelter donated to the impoverished Cité Soleil neighborhood by an international NGO but subsequently seized by the gang. Gang activity is raging out of control in the Haitian capital, Port au Prince, with abductions, kidnappings for ransom, and warfare among gangs for control of territory. Often gang members are minors or even teenagers.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @enricsala / Vostok Island, Kiribati: The team at @natgeopristineseas travels to the wildest places in the ocean to explore locations that still look like they did 500 years ago, in order to have the best understanding of a healthy marine ecosystem. These places are the blueprint. The instruction manual. Maybe we cannot bring all of the ocean back to this state, but these places show us the potential. They give us hope. For more on protecting our oceans, follow @enricsala.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: The male Victoria’s riflebird doesn’t have the world’s most melodious call, but boy does he have the dance moves! In Queensland, Australia’s rainforest, riflebirds (a bird of paradise) choose a display pole, and when their call draws in a female, put on a performance to try to be chosen as her mate. You’ll find a video of the full display behavior @TimLaman. #VictoriasRiflebird #birdsofparadise #Queensland #Australia #dancing

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Cristina Mittermeier @Mitty / I waited patiently on the banks with my camera in hand and listened for the telltale signs of a massive creature: a rustling in the brush or maybe even a low growl. But when the spirit bear finally emerged on the far side of the river, it stepped carefully over the moss, as quiet as an apparition, and settled on its haunches to test the air. A smile tugged at the corner of its mouth while it took several giant sniffs through its long snout. This incredible animal is a subspecies of the American black bear with a special recessive gene that makes it all white. They live deep in the cedar and fir forests of British Columbia and are considered endangered. But thanks to the tireless efforts of Indigenous communities, who consider the bears to be sacred, they have been shielded from poaching for generations and we are still working on expanding protections for them today. Follow me @mitty as I work with my partner @PaulNicklen and our team @SeaLegacy to help preserve British Columbia’s wilds and protect the futures of animals like this. #greatbearrainforest #spiritbear #kermodebear #beautifulbc

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen / Unaccompanied refugee minors and older refugees from Pakistan and Afghanistan offer evening prayers, known as maghrib, in a makeshift mosque set up outside abandoned warehouses where they took refuge, in Belgrade, Serbia. This image was part of my story “Young and Stranded,” published in the December 2017 issue of National Geographic. For more photos and videos of the refugee crisis, follow me @mmuheisen @mmuheisenpublic. For more on how to get involved, follow @everydayrefugees. #muhammedmuheisen #everydayrefugees

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @paoloverzone / A cadet of the École navale in Lanvéoc-Poulmic, France. Created in 1830, the École navale is the French naval academy, originally based on ships (like the famous Borda) in the harbor of Brest. After WWII, the academy moved to its site in Lanvéoc-Poulmic, close to Brest. This portrait is part of the Cadets series I photographed in 20 European military academies, located in 16 countries. Follow @paoloverzone for more photos and stories.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto / In Borneo, Indonesia, some farmers clear land the easy way… by lighting fires illegally, burning not only the tropical rainforest but also destroying the world’s largest natural terrestrial carbon sink: the peatlands beneath. They're doing this to cash in on the growing demand for palm oil, the most widely consumed vegetable oil on the planet; its rapid expansion threatens some of the planet’s most sensitive habitats. For more on environmental issues, follow @paleyphoto #palmoil #borneo #indonesia #kalimantan

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @babaktafreshi / A face in profile—an iconic mountain in southeastern Iran—gazes at the stars. Photographed in 2007, this post is my tribute to the brightest star of Persian classical music, Shajarian, who recently passed away after a long battle with cancer. A true master, known for his almost 60 years of singing, composing, and humanitarian activities. But one thing that is less noted was his passion for the night sky. Being an astronomy journalist, I first realized about this 20 years ago, when he called me to discuss his interest. He received the Mozart Medal from UNESCO and is listed in NPR's 50 Great Voices of the World, but beyond these he won the heart of many Iranians and left an eternal legacy that continues through the Shajarian family and his thousands of students.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @ciriljazbec / One way to fight climate change: Make your own glaciers. The Zingral ice "stupa" was constructed from sprayed water by a group of students, just below Chang La Pass, one of the tourist destinations of Ladakh.

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @johnstanmeyer / Rajib Kutum, 35, in Upar Chumaimari village on Majuli Island in Assam, India, pumps all the water out of his fishpond to collect the fish he’s been farming. An agricultural farmer and a fish farmer, Rajib loses his fish farm when the monsoon season arrives and all the land is covered by the waters of the Brahmaputra River. Majuli is the world’s largest river island. The image is from my latest story in the August issue of @natgeo magazine, "Water Everywhere, and Nowhere," now on newsstands worldwide. @outofedenwalk #walkingindia #edenwalk #india #majuli #assam

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto / From my Toy Stories series: This is Julius, 3, from Lausanne, Switzerland. Toy Stories is an ongoing project—wherever I travel in the world, I take portraits of children with their favorite toys. In three years, I've visited over 50 countries, where I've recorded the spontaneous and natural joy that unites kids, despite their diverse backgrounds. Whether the child owns a veritable fleet of miniature cars or a single stuffed monkey, the pride that they have is moving, funny, and thought-provoking. Follow me @gabrielegalimbertiphoto for more photos and stories. #toys #play #kids #child #children

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman / Today Deb Haaland was announced as president-elect Joe Biden’s nominee for secretary of the Interior. If confirmed, Haaland will be the first Native American to serve as a Cabinet secretary. I photographed her for @natgeo in 2018, when Haaland was in the midst of her successful run for Congress.

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @hannahreyesmorales / Over the last year, we’ve been exploring what might be the very first love songs that we hear: lullabies. We wanted to find out what bedtime looked and sounded like for families around the world. We carry lullabies across borders and create new ones along the way. Mona, a Syrian refugee living in Turkey, tells us that for her, the lullaby is a "window into the caregivers’ soul." Here she’s seen with her first grandchild, Zaid, in their home in Hatay. In 2013 Mona fled Syria and joined her son in Turkey, where Zaid was born.

“As Arabs, we have a proverb: No one is more worthy than your child but your grandchild,” she says. She sings songs to him in the hope that he might know a piece of Syria where his family is from.

Read more on lullabies in the December issue of @natgeo. #livinglullabies #Mongolia @insidenatgeo @timstrust

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @dina_litovsky / A night scene in the Meatpacking District, New York City. Taking inspiration from Edward Hopper’s night paintings, I walk around after sunset looking for sources of light, which offers refuge from the alienating darkness. For more images, follow me @dina_litovsky.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by Michael Yamashita @yamashitaphoto / Aquaculture: Some of China's largest fish farms, along with oyster and shellfish beds, can be found in the shallow seas, mudflats, and bays near Xiamen. Marco Polo in the 13th century was the first to describe the practice of aquaculture to the west. He encountered the cultivation of fish in lakes, ponds, and other enclosures during his travels in China. The Chinese originated the practice, utilizing fish cultivation techniques as far back as 2,000 BC. Today China, with one-fifth of the world's population, accounts for two-thirds of the world's aquaculture production, making the country the global leader. #aquaculture #fishfarm #oysterfarm #shellfishfarm

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / Working in the field of conservation and climate change, as I do, it's easy to have a depressed, doomsday outlook. When I look into the innocent eyes of my son, however, I'm empowered—to keep working hard and continue to seed the message that we as a species need to do better for the health of the next generation and our planet as a whole. Here's to hope, perseverance, and a better future.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Nat Geo photography David Guttenfelder (@dguttenfelder) captured the Balancing Rock formation at Stockton Island, one of the 21 Apostle Islands in Lake Superior. 2020 marks the 50th year since the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore was designated a park; we marked the moment by kayaking along the island shorelines and hiking around the unique islands, which are Ojibwe Native lands.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @celestesloman / On December 17, President-elect Joe Biden nominated Haaland to lead the Interior Department. If confirmed by the Senate, Haaland, a congresswoman from New Mexico, would be the first Native American to lead a cabinet-level agency. I took this portrait when I worked on a project that portrayed the women of the 116th Congress.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Anastasia Taylor-Lind @anastasiatl / An Armenian combatant wounded in the battle for Shusha, which Armenians call Shushi, is admitted at a medical center in Stepanakert, Nagorno-Karabakh, on November 6.

The war between Azerbaijan and Armenia lasted for six weeks, ending on November 10 with a Russian-mediated peace deal that left Azerbaijan retaining territory gained during the war and regaining control of districts surrounding Nagorno-Karabakh that Armenia had captured in the 1990s.

This work was supported by the National Geographic Society’s Emergency Fund for Journalists.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @amivitale / Hooded, sedated lions are transported and unloaded in Mozambique as villagers watch. Lions’ eyes don’t close when the animals are sedated, so they’re fitted with hoods to protect their eyes from the light. These lions were part of an international transfer of 24 lions from South Africa, the largest lion relocation ever undertaken. After years of civil war in Mozambique, lions were all but lost in the Zambezi Delta region. Just a few decades ago, prides of lions once roamed the game-rich wetlands. But their numbers were decimated when their prey was overhunted during the drawn-out Mozambican civil wars, which raged from 1977 to 1992. Across Africa, a similar decline is occurring, with wild lion numbers dropping 42 percent in the last two decades, mostly as a result of habitat loss. This translocation has restored the apex predator to its ancestral lands, and it is estimated that the population could grow to as many as 500 within 15 years. Already, more than 35 cubs have been born since the lions’ release.

I covered this historic undertaking for my @natgeo story. Learn more by following @amivitale and reading "How the world’s largest lion relocation was pulled off."
@zambezedeltaconservation @thephotosociety #lions #stoppoaching #africa #oneeyeopen #mozambique

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @mattiasklumofficial / The forest cobra is native to central and western Africa. It's the largest true cobra species, with a length up to 3.1 meters (10 feet). (I've also photographed the king cobra, which is much bigger but is the sole member of its own genus.) The forest cobra (and the king cobra) is a capable swimmer and is often considered to be semiaquatic. My team and I searched in lowland forests and moist savanna habitats for this beautiful species during an assignment in Cameroon—and eventually got lucky! It's a fast snake and it has a reputation of being hyper-alert and sometimes nervous. With that and a strong venom, it's considered very dangerous. Bites to humans are less common than with other African cobras but still a life-threatening emergency.

Ironically the lethal characteristics of snake venom make it so valuable and sought after for use in medicinal treatments. The toxic components of snake venom have, for example, led to the development of medicine against heart disease, diabetes, and Alzheimer's. With a bit of luck, the forest cobra may soon combat heart disease and not affect the wild populations of this species at all. #protectbiodiversity #medicine #cobra #africa #forestcobra

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Scientists have learned more about dinosaurs in the last 25 years alone than in the previous two centuries. In our newest augmented-reality experience, capture life-size dinosaurs in your space and learn about the latest findings that upended what we know about the ancient beasts. You also can use the selfie mode and share videos of yourself as the dinosaur. Thanks to groundbreaking science, we’ve learned that this dinosaur, Yi qi, had wings and could glide. To try out the dinosaur AR filters for yourself, watch the Dino AR Instagram Story in our highlights or click on the AR tab at the top of our page (it’s the little smiley face on the right). #reimaginingdinosaurs #AR

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @babaktafreshi / Sand Dunes in Moonlight: As I hiked on this crystal-clear November night, I was waiting for a surreal moment—for the last rays of a setting moon to shine on the dunes. The sky became darker and filled with stars as the moon approached the horizon. The Great Sand Dunes National Park in Colorado has an unusual location. The small, high-elevation desert is surrounded by the Rocky Mountains, and it has the tallest sand dunes in the North America. Explore more of the world at night with me @babaktafreshi. #twanight #earth #desert #greatsanddunesnationalpark

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @lucalocatelliphoto / At the Koppert Kress greenhouse in Monster, the Netherlands, microgreens, appreciated by chefs worldwide, are grown with the help of powerful LED lights in combination with natural sunlight, which is let in through automated curtains on the glass roof.

By 2050 Earth will be home to as many as 10 billion people. If increases in agricultural yield are not achieved, a billion or more may face food shortages. Greenhouses could offer a solution to humanity's future needs—and they reduce dependence on water by as much as 90 percent, and in some cases almost completely eliminate the use of chemical pesticides.

Follow me @lucalocatelliphoto to learn more about the promising new solutions for the pressing issues facing our planet. #environment #circulareconomy #greenhouse #netherlands #lucalocatelliphoto

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown / Children play soccer in Kibati, just north of Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, where it is the most popular sport. Soccer is played by approximately 250 million players in over 200 countries and dependencies, making it the world's most popular sport too. Follow @michaelchristopherbrown for more human stories from around the world.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by Michael Yamashita @yamashitaphoto / Winterized: The weather in Japan reaches extremes, from hot, humid summers to frigid, icy winters, and for centuries gardeners there have employed beautiful yet practical ways to protect trees from the harshness of winter. Transforming trees into sculptural objects through yukizuri–the art of supporting tree limbs against the weight of heavy wet snow with artfully tied ropes–is an annual autumn ritual throughout Japan. Tree trunks are protected by kokomaki–wraps made of straw–in an organic form of pest control that creates a cozy spot for the pine moth (in its caterpillar stage) to roost for the winter, rather than its usual hibernation spot under fallen leaves on the ground. In the spring, gardeners collect and burn the wraps filled with still-groggy caterpillars before they are able to gobble up the pine needles and damage the tree. #Japan #yukizuri #JapaneseGarden #Japanese

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @joelsartore / The European eel is one of a few species that spend most of their lives living in freshwater but journey to salt water in order to breed. They travel over 3,000 miles to the Sargasso Sea, making their migration one of the most impressive observed in the animal kingdom. The migration, while remarkable, leaves the species open to a number of threats, including predation, pollution, and fishing impacts. At one point, European eels were also caught as juveniles and farmed in the U.K. and other parts of Europe. The spread of this trade internationally is believed to have contributed to the decline in wild populations and ultimately to this species' endangered status. Photo taken at the Environmental Education Center of the Ribeiras de Gaia in Portugal. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk #savetogether

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by George Steintmetz @geosteinmetz / A turkey farm in Clayton County, Iowa. Confined animal feeding operations like this produce most of the meat consumed in the industrialized world. They are extremely efficient but also extremely prone to population collapse with uniform genetics. These birds were being sprayed with a non-toxic disinfectant to prevent a poultry pandemic. To see more about where our food comes from, follow my other account @FeedThePlanet.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @nataliekeyssar / The New York City borough of Queens, a community largely composed of essential and front-line workers, was hit very hard by the first wave of the pandemic in the spring. The resulting economic fallout has been catastrophic for the community there, leaving thousands of people struggling to put food on the table while still paying their bills. In response to the overwhelming need, nonprofits, aid groups, churches, and government organizations, as well as private citizens and volunteers, have come together to donate and distribute food all over the city. One such program is CENTI, a community church where every Tuesday, church members and volunteers hand out boxes of groceries from the USDA to hundreds of Queens residents who often wait in line for hours for the help.

Here, Ciria Santiago (second from the left) joins a group of volunteers in packaging the food after the truck from USDA arrived. Ciria, who lost her business due to the pandemic, volunteers at several food handout sites each week because she prefers to spend the time she would otherwise spend in line for food helping instead. At the end of the day she takes home her own box of food to her family. Centi is passing out over 500 bags of food a week and doesn't see the demand slowing down any time soon.

Follow me, @nataliekeyssar, for more stories about resilience in hard times.

@FeedingAmerica is the nation’s largest hunger-relief organization with a network of 200 food banks and 60,000 food pantries and meal programs that together provide food to more than 40 million people per year. Learn more at our link in bio. #FeedTheLove

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: A time-lapse of plough snails feeding on a beached barrel Jellyfish off the coast of South Africa. These snails are important scavengers in coastal ecosystems and can smell decay from a considerable distance. Nat Geo photographer Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski stumbled upon this feeding frenzy while walking along the beach at sunrise.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @tamaramerino_photography / The Aghor are a cult that consume human flesh for some rituals—from corpses routinely found floating in the Ganges—and immerse themselves in environments where death surrounds them as part of their daily routine. They live and perform their rituals in cremation grounds, but despite their extreme practices and lifestyle, a true Aghor will never hurt another being. To become an Aghor, each member of the sect has to spend at least 12 years learning and practicing from his personal guru. Baba Ram Mahesh, on the left, is the guru of Pandi, who has been learning from him for almost five years. Follow me on @tamaramerino_photography to see the full story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @maddiemcgarvey / Autumn and Sydney King play outside their home in Maysel, part of Clay County, West Virginia. The girls live with their mother, Jennifer, and grandmother, Helen, about a 45-minute drive from the nearest major grocery store. They also don’t have a car, which, in much of rural West Virginia, is an existential worry. No car means no way to get to work, no way to get to the doctor’s office, no way to get food. Jennifer and Helen pay friends and family members to drive them to Walgreens, in Clay, to pick up medicine, or Sam’s Club, in Charleston, to go grocery shopping; this costs between 10 and 30 dollars every trip, which adds up, and can be difficult to afford with a fixed income.

@FeedingAmerica is the nation’s largest hunger-relief organization with a network of 200 food banks and 60,000 food pantries and meal programs that together provide food to more than 40 million people per year. Learn more at our link in bio. #FeedTheLove

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @amivitale / Wildlife ranger Kamara walks with three baby rhinos he looks after at Lewa Wildlife Conservancy. Rangers like him literally put their lives on the line to protect and care for these animals every day. Thanks to their work and investment in the local communities, @lewa_wildlife has not lost a single rhino to poaching in five years. Ranger units have significantly improved the security of wildlife and people in the neighboring areas.The conservancy today is home to 14% of Kenya's rhinos.

Unfortunately, right now, communities like this one are struggling because of the pandemic, which has caused tourism to vanish. The threat to their livelihoods and to nature grows ever greater. All over Africa, conservationists have reported an increase in illegal bushmeat hunting, and they fear organized poaching of rhino horn and ivory could be next. Learn more, including how to help, by following @amivitale and @lewa_wildlife. @thephotosociety @photography.for.good #kenya #conservation #rhinos #africa

Post description: Photo by @kiliiiyuyan / Newborn Greenlandic huskies bask in the warmth of their mother in Ilulissat, Greenland. Greenlandic huskies are a carefully protected working breed, and no other breed of dog is permitted north of the village of Sisimiut. Greenland's laws have shaped a democracy based on Indigenous priorities. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the Arctic region. #Greenland #arctic #husky

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: A baby orangutan, born in the wild last year in Borneo, represents the future for this critically endangered species. Filmed by @timlaman in Indonesia's Gunung Palung National Park, which harbors one of the remaining wild orangutan populations, being studied by my wife, Nat Geo explorer Cheryl Knott, and her team. Follow @SaveWildOrangutans to learn more about the conservation work they do to safeguard the wild orangutans of Borneo. Only wild-born orangutans have the chance to learn all that they need from their moms to survive in the forest. #orangutan #Borneo #Indonesia #endangeredspecies #GunungPalungNationalPark

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @paulnicklen / Walruses are among the largest pinnipeds and can weigh up to 3,300 lbs (1,500 kg), which is 500 lbs (200+ kg) more than the average car. Their prehistoric, saber-like tusks arc elegantly towards the ice, growing to three feet (a meter) or longer over a lifetime. Yet despite their fearsome appearance, they are surprisingly gentle. This male was easily the largest walrus I had ever seen, but my intention was to paint him as the mellow, contemplative individual he was by contrasting his formidable presence with the serenity of an Arctic landscape. Follow me @paulnicklen as I attempt to unearth the beauty hidden within our planet's most powerful creatures. #walrus #svalbard #norway #wildlife #animalkingdom

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @celestesloman / This is a portrait of Keyt dancing with seagulls on Brighton Beach in Brooklyn. Keyt is a Russian taxi driver who I met on Brighton Beach and have photographed many times over the past few years.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @iantehphotography / This is from one of my earliest trips to the U.S., circa 2000. I remember dashing to keep up with this stretch limo as it passed under a U.S. flag in Times Square during rush hour. At the time, the scene felt like a visual shorthand for America, her excesses and a free-market economic system on steroids fueling her dynamism. I loved the city, and of course, that was before 9/11, the 2008 global financial crisis, and more recently, the COVID-19 pandemic. The world certainly seems much more complicated, polarized, and angry now—and none more so than in the U.S. After the recent 96 angst-ridden hours, America has a new president-elect who seeks to heal deep national divisions while demonstrating a willingness to rejoin international efforts to face urgent global challenges like a warming planet. Civilization can be a thin veneer—often taken for granted, it doesn’t take much for chaos to set in. Follow me on @iantehphotography to see slices of daily life from around the world. #nyc #USA #throwback #timesquare

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman / Salish and Kootenai teenagers gather around a campfire after a long day at hunting camp on the Flathead Reservation in western Montana. Over the course of the week, they go out with experienced hunters who teach them how to hunt, skin, clean, cut, and smoke deer and elk. The gathering is rooted in preserving and passing on Native traditions, from the early morning dip they take in the Flathead River to telling stories about their day every evening. At the end of the week, the smoked meat is distributed to members of the community. #nativeamericanheritagemonth

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Video by @bertiegregory / For such a large animal, the basking shark's eyes aren’t very big. It’s thought that their eyesight isn’t needed to detect plankton, and just used to dodge strange objects (like me!) and to determine the light level. Just behind the eyes is the brain. Poet Norman MacCaig described basking sharks as "That room-sized monster with a matchbox brain." Despite being able to grow to more than 10m/30ft, their brains are only about 10cm long. Unlike their great white cousins, which actively and strategically hunt fast-moving prey, it’s thought that basking sharks’ evolutionary needs don’t include a big brain: plankton doesn’t exactly run away. Basking sharks also can’t afford the energy required for a large brain, as their prey isn’t energy-rich seals. So if they’ve got bad eyesight and a tiny brain, how do they find their food? Well, smell is the secret weapon. In fact, their nerval mass for smell is actually bigger than their brain. Follow @bertiegregory for more wildlife adventures!

#britishwildlife #underwater #freediving #baskingshark #shark #scotland

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @jimmychin / Tapovan base camp, under Shivling mountain, in the Garwhal Himalaya. For more images of the last wild places on Earth, follow @jimmychin.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @enricsala / Tierra del Fuego, Argentina: The wild is our life-support system. A healthy planet benefits humans and allows us to flourish. There is a growing realization that every ecosystem on Earth is connected. In the past, people thought that climate change would affect somebody else, that biodiversity decline was just a problem in the Amazon, or that an outbreak of Ebola was just an issue in Central Africa. But the COVID-19 pandemic’s rapid spread across the globe is the loudest wake-up call we’ve had so far that the destruction of nature affects us all. For more on the benefits of protecting our land and oceans, follow @enricsala.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @erintrieb / One year ago, in November 2019, thousands of Iraqis organized to protest Iraq’s sectarian political system and government corruption. For several months Iraqi youth occupied central Baghdad, where hundreds of protestors were killed and thousands injured, prompting Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi to resign. COVID-19 brought Iraq’s protests to a halt, but the impact of the protests continues to be felt. Here, a young Iraqi taunts Iraqi security forces from atop a tuk-tuk after Iraqi security forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets. For more human stories from around the world follow @erintrieb.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto / Here lies the Grand Canyon-like passage of Škocjanske jama (cave) in Slovenia. It is a deep underground gorge that has been carved out over hundreds of thousands of years as the Reka River makes its way to the sea. Getting the chance to photograph this has been a dream come true, and one made even better by the atmospheric misty air hanging at the bottom of the cave.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @kiliiiyuyan / Ears of heritage corn display a rainbow of colors at the Onondaga Nation Farm in upstate New York. Onondaga tribal member Angela Ferguson manages a massive seed library of thousands of varieties of Indigenous corn found nowhere else. They are the genetic memory of generations of ancestors across the Americas. Today, most of the world’s calories come from just five crops, including corn, and resilience to climate change and pests is heavily bolstered by Indigenous heritage varieties. For the Onondaga, nutritious varieties of corn are security during uncertain times—such as the COVID pandemic—because they have grown and set aside years' worth of food for their members.

We owe a debt of gratitude to Indigenous peoples for their continuing stewardship of staples, from potatoes to beans. During Native American Heritage Month, we can pay our respects by becoming more aware of the modern Indigenous peoples in a single, simple way—by getting to know someone Native in your own community. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the Indigenous perspective. #nativeamericanheritage #haudenosaunee #corn

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @sarahyltonphoto / Angeline Cheek, an environmental activist and member of the Fort Peck Indian Reservation in Montana, stands beside the Missouri River. Cheek has been active in opposing the proposed Keystone XL pipeline, a controversial extraction project that President Trump reintroduced in 2017 and that President-elect Biden has promised to shut down. The proposed pipeline would cross through the Missouri River just south of the reservation: “This is our medicine,” she said, referring to the plants and herbs used by Native American communities for medicinal and ceremonial purposes—and which she fears could be contaminated by a pipeline spill. For more stories, follow me @sarahyltonphoto. #Montana #keystonexl #environment
