Parthenon temple is illuminated atop the ancient Acropolis, with the Saronic Gulf seen in the background, in Athens, Greece. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #muhammedmuheisen #Greece #Athens #Acropolis

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Video by @joelsartore / Uroplatus sameiti is a species of leaf-tailed gecko endemic to the island of Madagascar. The eyes of this species are large and lidless, with cat-like vertical pupils that are well suited for the species’ nocturnal habits. Skin coloration has developed as camouflage, with most geckos being grayish brown or greenish brown—colors that are meant to resemble tree bark, moss, and lichen. To see another clip of this species, follow me @joelsartore. #gecko #bigeyes #tongue #PhotoArk #savetogether

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Diana Markosian @markosian / A fleet of buses departs every morning from the capital of Yerevan, Armenia, taking families back to their homes in Nagorno-Karabakh. The disputed region experienced a six-week war between Armenia and Azerbaijan, ending in a cease-fire brokered by Russia and a loss of most territories controlled by the republic.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag / Cuajinicuilapa, Guerrero, Mexico. Portrait of a devil from the Diablos de Coyantes dancing group. The Danza de Diablos (dance of the devils) was created in the Mexican west, more precisely in the Costa Chica, known as the Afro-Mexican territory. It is a dance of rebellion and protest. It is the manifestation of the cultural force of African roots. Follow me at @lujanag to learn more about this and other stories.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Video by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / A time-lapse of fireflies dancing under vibrant skies at twilight in Brazil’s Pantanal region. This scene was surreal to witness, a bioluminescent 360-degree display that danced around me. Fireflies create their bioluminescence through a chemical reaction where oxygen, calcium, adenosine triphosphate, and luciferin are combined. What this video fails to show is the outrageous abundance of mosquitos that tormented me while shooting this. I paid a heavy blood tax, but it was worth it to witness this remarkable scene! To see more from the Pantanal please visit @ladzinski.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @tamaramerino_photography / Nerea's white dress hangs in the corridor of the cave where she lives in Guadix, a region in southern Spain containing around 2,000 caves—used as homes for generations—spread over an area of 200 hectares (500 acres). Most are occupied, with about 4,500 citizens. The rocky formations first served as a sanctuary from wild storms and predatory animals. Later, they offered protection from religious and racial persecution. Now the structures are home to quietly proud communities who have eschewed modern life for the peaceful solitude of the mountains. This photo is part of my series Underland, which documents communities living underground or in caves around the world. And each of the communities I’ve documented—from Australia and Spain to the United States—have their own socio-cultural, environmental, economic, or religious reason for living underground. Follow me on @tamaramerino_photography for more photos from Underland. #caves #undergroundhouse #underland

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Pete McBride @pedromcbride / The quiet dance of the Arctic lights was a spellbinding finish to a cold day on the icy ocean. The northern lights, also known as aurora borealis, emerge in the sky when the sun's outermost plasma drives the solar wind toward Earth. The particles collide with nitrogen and oxygen atoms in the atmosphere, creating ions that give off the colors that light up the sky. This natural phenomenon has fascinated people for centuries, and it is even thought to be depicted in a cave painting dating back to 30,000 B.C.

For more quiet places, follow @pedromcbride. #nature #northernlights #Norway #humbled #PeteMcBride

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Video of @bertiegregory by Charlie Gregory / Here's a behind the scenes look at filming basking sharks. Despite their enormous size, these basking sharks can be surprisingly skittish, especially if you’re freediving (the splash created by your fins can spook them). I found the best strategy was to anticipate their arrival and dive down well before they approached. My expert guides Shane and Isla gave critical tips and tricks on predicting their path. These included fast (but quiet!) swimming with your head above the water, watching the orientation of the dorsal fin, as well as analyzing the streaky tide lines that the sharks follow. I get a lot of messages asking for advice on wildlife filming. No matter how much you think you know, listen intently to local experts. Given the amount of time they spend in their location, the insights they can give you are invaluable. Follow @bertiegregory for more wildlife adventures. #britishwildlife #underwater #freediving #baskingshark #shark

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @kiliiiyuyan / A young polar bear investigates the recently butchered carcass of a bowhead whale. While spring and fall whale hunts provide a source of food for the bears, the fall hunt is especially critical for bears on the verge of starvation—caused by reduced pack ice in the summer months. Many Iñupiat prefer to let the bears feed, provided they maintain a safe distance from people. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan, for more about the human relationship to wildlife. #alaska #polarbear #arctic

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Juan Arredondo @juanarre / Bocas de Barbacoas, in Antioquia, Colombia. The marshland of Barbacoas contains great natural diversity and is in the process of becoming a sanctuary. It's under threat from sprawling cattle farms; local fishermen have seen a decline in the native fish upstream from the marshland along the Magdalena River, the principal river of Colombia. Follow @juanarre for more stories.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto / This is an old photo from my ongoing project Toy Stories. Wherever I travel in the world, I take portraits of children with their favorite toys. I have spent more than two years visiting over 50 countries, and I've recorded the spontaneous and natural joy that unites kids, despite their diverse backgrounds. Whether the child owns a veritable fleet of miniature cars or a single stuffed monkey, the pride that they have is moving, funny, and thought-provoking. This is Enea, 3, in Castiglion Fiorentino, Italy. Follow me @gabrielegalimbertiphoto for more photos and stories. #toys #play #kids #child #children

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @paolowoods / The graduation ceremony for the teacher’s college at the Université Publique du Sud, in the city of Les Cayes, Haiti.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @lucalocatelliphoto / A worker untangles freshly recycled wool in Prato, Italy. Wool is the most common and successfully recycled textile worldwide—in Prato, this industry is a historic tradition.

According to the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, of the 100 million tonnes of textile waste produced every year, only 1% is recycled. Since the early 1900s, this small Tuscan town sorts and repurposes over 15% of the world’s textiles that entered the recycling loop. What was considered a discarded item is today a commodity and a symbol for sustainable industrial production.

Prato and its recycling industry were the subject of National Geographic magazine's March issue cover story on "The End of Trash"—circular economy solutions. By designing waste out of the production system, circularity aims to keep resources and materials in use while regenerating natural systems.

While the circular economy is promising, the truth is there isn't one single solution. Yet each one of us can make a big difference by living more consciously and staying informed. Follow me @lucalocatelliphoto to learn how we can make a difference.
#environment #circulareconomy #fashion #italy #lucalocatelliphoto

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @beverlyjoubert / Huge animals have huge water needs—hundreds of liters each day, in fact. And when those days get particularly hot, water is also lost on a massive scale. New research shows elephants can lose as much as 10% of their total body water (that’s almost as much as two full bathtubs) a day when temperatures soar. It’s nothing to worry about so long as lost stores can be quickly replenished … but in a world that’s rapidly warming and on a continent increasingly plagued by drought, life-giving water holes and water-rich plants are becoming ever more scarce. For an iconic giant with water needs to match, this spells trouble ahead. #elephants #endangeredspecies #climatechange #waterislife

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @hannahreyesmorales / Over the last year, we’ve been exploring what might be the very first love songs that we hear: lullabies. We wanted to find out what bedtime looked and sounded like for families around the world.

On a winter evening in Selenge Province, Mongolia, Oyunchimeg and her two girls get ready for bed. They left their home in the city of Ulaanbaatar, one of the world’s coldest and most air-polluted capitals. Oyunchimeg decided to move to the province, where the air is cleaner, following her daughters becoming ill from the hazardous levels of pollution in the city.

"I use these words to protect my children. They help my children heal," she says of the lullabies that she sang to her girls when they were unwell. Oyunchimeg sings traditional lullabies, but in between refrains she whispers healing words—reshaping a long established song for the present time.

Read—and listen to—our story on lullabies in the December issue of Nat Geo. Follow me @hannahreyesmorales as we journey exploring nighttime rituals around the world. #livinglullabies #Mongolia @insidenatgeo @timstrust

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @paulnicklen / The sun never fully broke the horizon during a two-week expedition by @sealegacy to the majestic fjords of northern Norway. I was lucky to freeze this moment and others in what little light there was, as the content we captured played a key role in keeping big oil out of this pristine Arctic ecosystem—a major win for conservation. When you see one of the most impressive apex predators ever to evolve shatter the ocean's glassy surface in an explosion of power and grace, you can't help but question the human desire to place ourselves on the highest pillar of the podium of species. Follow me @paulnicklen to see many more of my encounters with the evolutionarily flawless orcas of Norway. #fineart #orca #northernfjords #norway #apexpredator

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photos by @martinschoeller / Ytite, Kokobiene, and Mangri, photographed in Turedjam, Terra Indígena Kayapó.

I photographed women of the Kayapo people, an indigenous group in the Brazilian Amazon, during a ceremony to bestow a “beautiful” name on a child. For this important occasion everybody must be painted and adorned.

The ceremony lasted for several days and nights, culminating in the final all-night ritual of dancing and singing.

I was fascinated by these women's creativity and the inventive, elaborate use of only two colors. Contrary to the concealing and augmenting purposes of make-up employed in Western cultures, in which everyone strives to achieve a narrow ideal of glamorized beauty, these women use face paint to indicate their stage of life, place in the community, and role in the ceremony and to honor hardships endured, while also expressing personal style and flair.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @stephenwilkes / Took a drive a few weeks ago to photograph for my new series Autumn Drive-by, celebrating the lovely fall on the East Coast. These are single captures taken as we were driving through Westport, Connecticut. Number three in the series. To see more from my travels near and far follow me @stephenwilkes. #fall #foliage #impressionism #westportct

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @celestesloman / This is a portrait of Baba, who I photographed at a Black Lives Matter protest in Harlem, New York City. It's part of a larger series I took as the Black Lives Matter movement grew following the death of George Floyd, an unarmed Black man killed in police custody in Minneapolis on May 25. I met Baba while marching through Harlem at a peaceful vigil for Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old Black woman who was fatally shot in her Louisville, Kentucky, apartment on March 13.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @jimmychin / James Pearson and Caro Ciavaldini on the first ascent of the Arch of Bishekele, in Chad's Ennedi Desert. Finding first ascents on notable formations requires patience, a willingness to search the far corners of the planet, a bit of grit, and often a dash of luck. For more images of climbing adventures around the world, follow @jimmychin.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto / Kačna jama (cave) is the third longest cave in Slovenia. The iconic twin skylight portals allow explorers access inside, where the Reka River can be seen flowing steadily toward the coast. Engulfed in a shaft of daylight, a climber ascends a rope through one of the two portals on the way to the entrance above.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Cristina Mittermeier @Mitty / From my lookout at the top of Steeple Jason’s rocky hills, I watched them drift in on the shifting winds with wings outstretched like long swords. The gold haze of dusk settled on the ocean as I waited patiently for the perfect shot. The black-browed albatross regularly travels hundreds, sometimes thousands, of kilometers at a time in search of food on a wingspan of over two meters long—before it returns to its nesting grounds. Finally, one of the soaring giants filled my viewfinder and raced straight for me, slicing the sea mist in a display of perfect symmetry. I clicked the shutter and then watched it sweep silently overheard to find its nest in the steep slopes behind me. Albatross can live up to 70 years and spend their lives gliding across the ocean. I could only imagine the things it must have seen in its lifetime spent at sea. Follow me @Mitty to learn more about our planet’s incredible wildlife as I work with my team @SeaLegacy to protect our ocean. #albatross

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Stephen Alvarez @salvarezphoto / The Rumble Room is a five-acre underground expanse discovered deep in a cave on the Cumberland Plateau in Tennessee. The only way into the cave is via a long, low, wet crawl and a 200-foot rappel into the room. Beyond this room are miles and miles of huge passages unknown until cave explorer Marion O. Smith discovered the cave in the late 1990s.

I have always been fascinated by original physical exploration. The act of actually going somewhere that no one has been before is a privilege that few have ever had. Usually we associate the act with the deep ocean or outer space. However, a small group of dedicated cave explorers discovered, explored, and mapped Rumbling Falls cave practically in their own backyard. For more images from around the world and close to home check out @salvarezphoto.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @laurakmorton / Jessica and Chris Medina take a cruise to the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, California, on December 6. It was the last day of cruises for the company before temporarily suspending business due to a new stay-at-home order in the area, a response to rising COVID-19 cases. Founded in 1892, the historic Red and White Fleet launches its tours from the Fisherman’s Wharf neighborhood, the city’s main tourist destination. Supported by @InsideNatGeo’s Emergency Fund for Journalists I am currently working on a project on Fisherman’s Wharf to document the economic issues affecting communities that rely on tourism. For more from this story and photographs of people, places and culture follow along @laurakmorton.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen / On August 2, I captured the moon rising above the ancient marble columns of the Temple of Poseidon in Cape Sounion, Greece. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic #muhammedmuheisen #Moon #Greece #Athens

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner / White lions are not albino; they're leucistic, which means they have a recessive mutation of genes that cause their coats to be white to blonde, rather than tawny. A cub is born white only if both of parents carry the recessive gene. White lions once roamed wild in the Timbavati area of South Africa. Their presence threads through the cultural history of the Sepedi and Tsonga communities, who revered the white lion and considered it sacred, divine, sent from above. But decades of trophy hunting, first started by Europeans, wiped out the white lion's wild gene pool. They were also put in zoos and bred in captivity; today they are still put in canned hunts and as cute blue-eyed cubs put in petting zoos.

Putting pressure on exploitive places can help close them down—deeply research places with white lions before supporting them; many are not as “conservation oriented” as they state, especially not ones with lion cubs of any age. For more stories on the relationship between humans and wildlife, follow me @kaigner! #whitelion #bigcats #wildlifeexploitation #lions #southafrica

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @paoloverzone / Gara Sbaa, Morocco. Nizar Ibrahim, Ph.D., paleontologist and National Geographic Explorer, showing some fossils to his students during a scouting. For @natgeo I documented a Spinosaurus find here in the desert. Spinosaurus was one of the largest predatory dinosaurs of all time. It is named after the elongated dorsal spines that supported an enormous “sail” of skin. In contrast to other dinosaurs—which are predominantly terrestrial—a long list of anatomical features are indicative of Spinosaurus being adapted to live in freshwater, like crocodiles and hippopotamuses.

Follow @paoloverzone for more photos and stories.

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Science photographer @babaktafreshi has documented many of the world's observatories. Here a night begins at the 66-meter (210 ft) radio telescope in Parkes, Australia, known as the Dish. Venus, Mercury, and the New Moon are in a rare celestial conjunction in this time-lapse video. Explore more @babaktafreshi.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by Pete McBride @pedromcbride / The lens has introduced me to a remarkable array of humans. I often wonder where they are today. These unpublished portraits are just a few of the gentle, friendly souls I met in the tiny country of Bhutan, when I trekked 230 miles (370 km) for @natgeo across its northern Himalaya border. We traveled along an ancient yak herders' route over eleven high-mountain passes (some above 5,000 meters/16,000 ft) on what is considered today one of the hardest treks in the world, due to its length, elevation, and weather. In 28 days of hiking, I saw not one wheel. #travel #bhutan #humanity #portraits #petemcbride

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photos by @edkashi / A mountain of bagasse, the fibrous material left after sugar cane production, is loaded for use in the power generation station at the Usina São Manoel, where sugar and ethanol are produced in a 24/7 operation, in Sao Manoel, Brazil. Sugar cane contains only about 10% sugar. The other 90% is bagasse—the remains after the pulverizing and squeezing of sugar-bearing juice.

This image is from 2011, and today I read in the Economist about a new material for coffee cups of the future: waste from sugar cane. Zhu Hongli, a mechanical engineer at Northeastern University, and her colleagues describe the potential of bagasse as a biodegradable replacement for plastic disposable food containers. While this isn’t the first time this idea has been tested, Hongli found the potential missing ingredient: bamboo. She and her colleagues found that the new material is twice as strong as the plastic used to make cups and it can remain intact when filled with boiling water for almost two hours, long enough for practical use. Production would cost about half the price of biodegradable cups made from polylactic acid (fermented plant starch) and only slightly more than plastic cup production. #bagasse #sugarcane #brazil #reducewaste #reduceplastic

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo @jasperdoest / Newly formed dunes at the Sand Motor, an artificial, peninsula-like sandbank constructed off the coast of the Netherlands. With nearly a quarter of the country below sea level and another half sitting less than a meter (yard) above, its very existence is under constant attack. Ocean currents, wind, and waves were given free rein to spread the sand along the Delfland coast to help protect the Netherlands against rising sea levels. The Sand Motor is part of an innovative coastal maintenance effort. Since its construction, dozens of researchers from various universities and institutions have been following the development of the Sand Motor. Follow @jasperdoest to learn more about the human-nature connection. #zandmotor #sandmotor #coast #dunes #netherlands

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photos by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto / Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, has one of the world’s highest air pollution levels. Throughout the long winter months, the majority of people burn poor-quality coal to not only heat up their homes and yurts but also as fuel for cooking. For more on environmental issues worldwide, follow @paleyphoto #airpollution

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @estherhorvath / Football in the central Arctic Ocean during the MOSAiC expedition. On some occasions, the sea ice next to the ship was “open” for two hours in the evening so that expedition participants could play football or do a round with skies. Sometimes I just felt so frozen after being on the sea ice for long hours during the day that I did polar bear–watch duty and cheered the teams from the bridge instead.

This image is from my recent book “Into the Arctic Ice,” showing the largest Arctic Ocean expedition of our time. Please follow @estherhorvath for more polar stories.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @johnstanmeyer / The family of Ramesh Pandey agreed to be photographed as they prepared to cremate him in Prayagraj, on the bank of the Yamuna. His ashes will flow into the Ganges. Hindus believe that cremation at such a holy site frees the soul from the cycle of life and death. The image is from my latest story in @natgeo magazine, "Water Everywhere, and Nowhere," in the August issue, now on newsstands worldwide. @outofedenwalk #walkingindia #edenwalk #india #prayagraj #allahabad

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photos by Michael Yamashita @yamashitaphoto / Coal, the rock that burns. "It is a fact that all over the country [of] Cathay there is a black stone existing in beds in the mountains, which they dig out and burn like firewood.”

This is how Marco Polo described the widespread use of coal in China during his time there in the 13th century. In addition to providing heat, coal was used by the Chinese to power large numbers of ironworks. China is currently the largest producer and consumer of coal in the world, even though in September, President Xi Jinping pledged to make his country carbon-neutral by 2060. But in the far northern province of Liaoning coal still powers the local economy, and steam engines built in the 1980s belch black smoke as they haul coal from pit mines dug into the arid landscape. #coal #steamtrain #liaoning #China #locomotive

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Stephanie Sinclair @stephsinclairpix / A young girl rests inside her home, located in an impoverished neighborhood near New Delhi's 70-acre Ghazipur landfill. Tens of millions of girls may never return to school due to COVID-19 and are consequently more vulnerable to child marriage, early pregnancy, and domestic violence. As the new year approaches, let us resolve to dismantle the persistent economic and social barriers to education. I’ve spent the better part of my career focused on amplifying the voices of some of the world’s most at-risk girls. Follow me @stephsinclairpix and the nonprofit I founded, @tooyoungtowed, to learn more about how we can help girls live free from violence and determine the course of their own lives.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @babaktafreshi / With most of the planet’s landmass impacted by light pollution, the remaining dark sky places are natural treasures, both to observe the vastness of universe and as refuges for nocturnal species. This is a self-portrait on a lake in California's SIerras. Explore more of our planet's wonders at night @babaktafreshi and learn more about light pollution and how we can reduce it on darksky.org @idadarksky. #twanight #darkskies #lightpollution #nightsky

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @ciriljazbec / The giant Shara ice stupa in Ladakh, India. Ice stupas try to solve a water problem for the mountain communities of Ladakh. They have always suffered from droughts, but the situation became more dire in the last decades due to glacier retreat. These mini-glaciers store winter meltwater and slowly release it for the growing season in early spring, when water is most needed.

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Video by @joelsartore / The twisted beak of the white-winged crossbill might look strange, but it is perfectly designed for prying into spruce cones and extracting the seeds found within them. Crossbills are an irruptive species, which means they usually travel only short distances, but will occasionally move far outside their normal range if conditions, including food availability, in their home range are not suitable. The Wildlife Rehabilitation Center of Minnesota (@wrcmn), which cares for injured wildlife, has seen many cases like this in the last few months, and are caring for crossbills like this one until they are strong enough to return to the wild. Follow me @joelsartore to learn more about their wildlife-saving work! #crossbill #bird #WRCMN #PhotoArk #savetogether

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder / Approaching Lake Superior’s Outer Island, the most remote of the 21 Apostle Islands and more than 20 miles from the state of Wisconsin’s Bayfield Peninsula mainland. The Apostle Islands National Lakeshore was designated a national park in 1970 and established to preserve and share its naturally wild beauty. We marked the 50th anniversary by kayaking and hiking many of the unique islands. Outer Island is a critical habitat for migratory birds, especially for passerines, hawks, and falcons every fall.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown / Men wait for passengers to board a wooden cargo and passenger boat just off the island of Idjwi. The tenth largest lake island in the world, Idjwi is located in Lake Kivu, one of the African Great Lakes, which lies between the Democratic Republic of the Congo (D.R.C.) and Rwanda. Traveling between the D.R.C. cities of Goma and Bukavu, I crossed the lake many times in boats ranging from modern ferries to pirogues and handmade dugout canoes carved from a single tree trunk. In general, the less efficient the craft the cheaper the price, though the less expensive trips often make for the best adventures. Follow @michaelchristopherbrown for more human stories from around the world.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @dina_litovsky / A scene in West Village, New York City. Taking inspiration from Edward Hopper’s night paintings, I walk around after sunset, looking for artificial lights illuminating stores and restaurants. The lights offer a refuge from the alienating darkness of the streets. For more images of the night city, follow me @dina_litovsky.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @paolowoods / A lottery stand known in Haiti as a “borlette.” Haitians invest two billion dollars every year in these private lotteries—nearly a quarter of the country’s GNP. They are often referred to as banks, since the poor invest their money in them. Borlettes are found all over the country, even in the most remote and difficult-to-reach areas. This one is in open countryside on the road to Camp-Perrin, in the south of the country.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @mattiasklumofficial / The king cobra, our world’s longest venomous snake, photographed on assignment for @natgeo in Malaysian Borneo. This magnificent snake can grow to nearly 6 meters (19 feet) and feeds almost exclusively on other snakes. In this picture an adult king is devouring some kind of water snake inches away from my camera. Please go to @mattiasklumofficial for more of my images and films from around the world. #kingcobra #asia #cobra #borneo #venom

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / Professional climber Joe Kinder battles his way up steep limestone on the rim of a cave, high over the Mojave Desert in southwest Utah. For climbers, the winter months in North America are the prime time to hit the desert, where solitude can be found, rock is abundant, and the temperatures and conditions are ideal.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @sarahyltonphoto / Women bathe and pray in the Ganges River in the village of Fatuha, in India's state of Bihar. Different customs and cultures span the length of the river and its tributaries—it's the world's most populated river basin. For more stories, follow me @sarahyltonphoto. #India #Ganga #Bihar

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @amivitale / A lion looks up from his freshly caught wild prey at @loisaba_conservancy in Laikipia, in northern Kenya. Wide-ranging carnivores like lions are normally one of the first mammal species to be lost in areas shared with people and livestock. Their presence in a human-dominated landscape like this one is a symbol of a successful coexistence. Apex predators like lions play a vital role in maintaining a healthy balance in an ecosystem, impacting everything below them, from soil nutrients and disease, to plant, prey and scavenger populations. If lions are doing well then the entire ecosystem is likely doing well. In the long term, that means the ecosystem will be better able to support the people that also rely on it.

To learn more, follow @lionlandscapes, @loisaba_conservancy @nature_org @nature_africa, @peregrinefund and @tusk_org who are working together to promote coexistence between humans and lions for the benefit of people and nature in northern Kenya. Follow @amivitale for more photos of those working to achieve sustainable coexistence between people and wildlife. @kenyawildlifeservice @houstonzoo @sandiegozoo @thephotosociety #lions #kenya #conservation #africa

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Video by @joelsartore / Costa Rican lemur leaf frogs like these two @amphibianfoundation are a critically endangered species. Native to Costa Rica, Panama, and Colombia, populations are now almost entirely gone from Costa Rica and parts of western Panama. This massive decline is believed to be the result of habitat degradation and chytridiomycosis, a disease in amphibians caused by the chytrid fungus. You can help to protect frog species where you live by keeping your yard free of pesticides and fertilizers that run off into local waterways. Keeping these chemicals out of local water sources helps to protect habitats that frogs need to thrive. To see another video of this duo, follow me @joelsartore. #frog #endangered #bigeyes #PhotoArk

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @gabrielegalimbertiphoto and Juri De Luca / Fossils of long-extinct creatures aren’t just for museums. Today they're in homes and businesses, as wealthy collectors indulge a controversial hobby.

In Mandeville, Louisiana, Ana Maria Perdigao and her children Nicolas (11) and Isaac (8) are seen in their living room, which has a fantastic view of one of the state's quintessential swamps. Joseph Perdigao, the husband of Ana Maria, who is not pictured, said, "I bought this skull three weeks ago. It’s actually a birthday present that I gave to myself. I wanted to buy something beautiful to keep in our living room. I was looking on [the] internet for something connected to natural history, one of my big passions, and I found the website of a company specialized in finding, restoring, and selling dinosaurs fossils. I didn't know until that moment that I could buy a real fossil of [a] dinosaur or a cast of it. I immediately understood that that was exactly what I wanted for my house. So I bought this cast of Triceratops. I didn't say anything to my family until the dinosaur got here. They were positively shocked to see it when they came back home.” #dinosaur #dino #triceratops

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag / Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. A field worker herds a group of sheep at Estancia Viamonte. Currently Estancia Viamonte has around 6,000 sheep used for wool work. The ranch was founded in 1902 by the sons of Reverend Thomas Bridges, the region’s first European settler. I took this photo for my story about the "spinners at the end of the world," for which I documented the whole process of local textile creation, from the work in the field to the confection of the final piece. Follow me at @lujanag to learn more about my life and work in the southern island of Tierra del Fuego.

Post description: Photo by @kiliiiyuyan / A pomarine jaeger flies low over its nest on the tundra at Qupaluk, near Alaska’s Teshekpuk Lake. Pomarines depend on lemmings during breeding years and succeed only years with peaks of the lemming population. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan for more about the Arctic and beyond. #alaska #npr-a #arctic

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @beverlyjoubert / The disappearance of any species from an ecosystem can reshape and weaken its complex interconnections—but some species play such a unique and outsize role that their extinction would be catastrophic. More so than perhaps any other bird family, vultures—those misunderstood yet vitally important disposal workers of the avian world—would unravel ecosystems with their absence. And yet that possibility is becoming ever more real: on the African continent, seven of the 11 vulture species are now being pushed to the edge of extinction, with declines of between 80 and 90 percent over the past 50 years. The causes behind these collapsing populations are varied, but poisoning has emerged as perhaps the most serious threat—and 2020 saw a spate of devastating poisoning incidents. Unless we want to experience the dire consequences of their loss, we need to make these indispensable scavengers a conservation priority. #vultures #birds #scavengers #conservation

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @hannahreyesmorales / Over the last year, we’ve been exploring what might be the very first love songs that we hear: lullabies. We wanted to know what bedtime looked and sounded like for families around the world.

Six-year-old Xavier hugs his doll with toy hearing implants in his home in Massachusetts. Xavier is deaf and uses cochlear implants to help him hear. At night, he and his mom Jessica sing —and sign—lullabies together before going to bed. After singing, Jessica, says “I love you” out loud every night in case the implants fail. “I make sure to tell him in case it is the last thing he hears,” she says.

Read more about lullabies (and listen to Xavier and Jessica’s song) in the December issue of Nat Geo. Follow me @hannahreyesmorales as we journey exploring nighttime rituals around the world. #livinglullabies #Mongolia @insidenatgeo @timstrust

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @lucalocatelliphoto / Personnel with the 309th Aerospace Maintenance and Regeneration Group (AMARG) recover usable parts from helicopters and other aircraft at the Boneyard, a United States Air Force storage and maintenance facility in Tucson, Arizona. It holds nearly 4,400 aircraft, which makes it the largest aircraft storage and preservation facility in the world.

AMARG is part of my latest story for National Geographic magazine, on "The End of Trash"—or circular economy solutions. Could it be an example for other large-scale industries to be less wasteful?

By designing waste out of the production system, circularity aims to keep resources and materials in use while regenerating natural systems. It's promising, but the truth is there isn't one single solution. Yet each one of us can make a big difference by being more conscious of our choices and staying informed.

Follow me @lucalocatelliphoto to learn more. #environment #circulareconomy #boneyard #arizona #lucalocatelliphoto

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

When we finally start to consider members of other species as our brothers and sisters, we will discover true fulfillment. I hope my fine art goes some distance toward cultivating this sentiment. Jiuzhaighou is a world apart and quite simply the most photogenic spot in China. It is also the most popular and best managed forest reserve in China. It’s my personal vision of paradise, a photographer’s Shangri-la. #Sichuan #JiuzhaigouValley #JiuzhaiValley #Jiuzhaigou

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @katieorlinsky / In Alaska the dark days of winter also mean the beginning of sled dog racing season. Professional dog musher Ray Redington, Jr., the grandson of Iditarod founder Joe Redington, races during the 2015 Yukon Quest 1,000 Mile International Sled Dog race in Dawson City, Canada. Dog mushing has a long history in the north; over 3,000 years ago hunter-gatherer communities were using dogs to pull sleds in the Arctic Circle, and indigenous communities used sled dogs long before Europeans bred the animals for transportation and hauling as they colonized the region in the 19th century. It wasn’t until the 1960s, once highways were built and snowmobiles became widespread, that dogs were no longer needed for transport. Still, the practice of dog mushing remained a cultural and recreational activity in communities across the Arctic, and the world of competitive sled dog racing began.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @johnstanmeyer / National Geographic explorer and writer Paul Salopek rides a small boat across a body of water, the most direct path between Purnia and Lalganj, while walking through Bihar State in India. At this point in the @outofedenwalk, Paul had journeyed by foot, beginning in 2013 from Herto Buri, Ethiopia, more than 10,460 kilometers (6,500 miles) and over 2,200 days of walking. The photo is from my latest story in @natgeo's August 2020 issue, "Water Everywhere, and Nowhere," now on newsstands worldwide. @outofedenwalk #walkingindia #edenwalk #india #bihar #boat

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo By Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski / There is an undeniable novelty of enjoying a morning cup of coffee and seeing a giraffe curiously poke its head into the room. This is a morning occurrence at Giraffe Manor, a 12-room hotel located on the outskirts of Nairobi, Kenya. Originally built in the 1930s, this property over the years became a sanctuary for the highly endangered Rothschild giraffe—and to this day is home to a breeding program dedicated to the preservation of this dwindling species. To see more photos from this remarkable place, please visit @ladzinski.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown / Men in Kisangani, Democratic Republic of the Congo, load oversize logs onto cargo boats to be carried down the Congo River toward the capital of Kinshasa and on to the rest of the world. The Congo Basin, larger than the state of Alaska, contains the world’s second largest tropical forests, our second lung after the Amazon. Basin forests, a huge carbon sink holding roughly 8 percent of the world's forest-based carbon, are biodiversity hot spots accessed by an estimated 40 million Africans who survive through traditional livelihoods such as hunting, fishing, farming, and wood/charcoal production. According to a recent University of Maryland study, smallholder clearing in the DRC, the largest of the six countries with forests located inside the Basin, accounted for at least two-thirds of total Basin forest loss, with 92.2 percent of this clearing done mostly by farmers utilizing slash-and-burn to feed their families rather than logging, industrial agriculture, and other activities. The same study found that if the population of Basin countries, including the DRC, increases by an expected five fold in the coming decades, along with the likely addition of industrial-scale agriculture, the region’s primary forests are projected to be cleared by 2100. In the first 14 years of the 21st century, an area larger than the size of Bangladesh was felled in the Congo River Basin rainforest. Follow @michaelchristopherbrown for more human stories from around the world.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @acacia.johnson / At work under the full moon, Joe Kigutaq searches for polar bear tracks on the November sea ice near Arctic Bay, Nunavut. Twice a week, he drove his snowmobile 30 kilometers (about 20 miles) to a former mine site to check that bears hadn't broken into the facilities, and during the winter I lived with his family, he sometimes let me tag along. These drives were the first time I really came to grasp how the sea ice—a stark, lunar landscape often envisioned as desolate—is in fact a rich marine ecosystem, the living ocean just underfoot. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from the Arctic and beyond. #arctic #seaice #nunavut #inuit

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @paoloverzone / Fossalta di Piave Italy, Di.Ma. (Dino Makers) factory and lab. Antonio Massari—sculptor, decorator, and modelist—hand modeling the head of a Spinosaurus in clay. Spinosaurus was one of the largest predatory dinosaurs of all time. It is named after the elongated dorsal spines that supported an enormous “sail” of skin. In contrast to other dinosaurs—which are predominantly terrestrial—a long list of anatomical features indicate Spinosaurus was adapted to living in freshwater, like crocodiles and hippopotamuses.

Follow @paoloverzone for more photos and stories.

Check out Nat Geo's link in bio for more on this story.

Trump supporters gathered in the nation’s capital to protest the ratification of President-elect Joe Biden’s electoral college victory over Trump in the 2020 election, resulting in the storming of the Capitol.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by @adamfergusonstudio / Law enforcement from Washington, D.C.’s Metropolitan Police Department stand guard at the Capitol after a mob of rioters stormed the building earlier in the day. Supporters of President Trump organized what they called a “Stop the Steal” rally on January 6, the day set for ratifying President-elect Joe Biden’s electoral college victory in the 2020 election. After the building was cleared, the Senate resumed the electoral count.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by @adamfergusonstudio / A lone supporter of President Trump stands outside the U.S. Capitol, touting conspiracy theories, on the morning of January 7. Trump supporters gathered for a rally in the nation's capital the day before, and afterward a mob stormed the Capitol, as rioters sought to disrupt a vote to certify the results of the 2020 election and President-elect Joe Biden's victory over President Trump.

Follow @natgeointhefield for real-time coverage of this developing story.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photo by Cristina Mittermeier @Mitty / In the shallows of the Dominican Republic, I floated gently near this mother humpback and her young calf, barely moving my fins so as not to disturb them. The mother gently lifted her baby to the surface with all the care and tenderness of a brand-new parent home from the hospital for the first time. It was clear this mother loved her calf just as much I loved my own children, and I was honored that she trusted me enough to calmly swim in my presence. Having kids is part of the reason why I became a conservation photographer, and when I see mothers in the wild caring for their young with such devotion, I feel a renewed sense of purpose. Follow me @Mitty as I work with my team @SeaLegacy to restore and protect our ocean so animals like this can thrive for generations.

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by @babaktafreshi / An impressive display of lenticular clouds appeared right after sunset. Some lenticulars are reported as UFOs due to their flying saucer shape and bright reflection of the setting sun, moonlight, or city lights. Pilots try not to fly near these dense clouds to avoid turbulence, due to a sudden change of air pressure. Explore more Earth and sky photography with me @babaktafreshi. #sunset #nature #iceland

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description: Photos by @EdKashi / Scenes of organizing, packing, and preparing food distribution at the Houston Food Bank in Houston, Texas, on August 10, 2020. The Houston Food Bank, founded in 1982, is the nation's largest food bank, serving 18 counties in Texas. Since the coronavirus hit in early 2020, it has more than doubled the amount of food it distributes, reaching up to one million pounds of food a day distributed around Texas. #pandemicfoodcrisis #houston #foodscarcity #hunger #pandemichelp

Account description: National Geographic Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.
Post description:
Photo by Pete McBride @pedromcbride / Short days bring beautiful light—as well as certain challenges. Where I'm staying in northern Norway, we never see the sun. The other side of the bay gets about 30 minutes of sunshine if it isn’t cloudy or raining. As the region enters the Polar Night, where the sun never truly rises, this shady side is in for the long haul without sun for the next four months.

Long winters and seemingly endless darkness may break some, but research has shown that residents here have lower rates of wintertime depression than you might expect. I hope to retain the lessons of a positive attitude toward winter when returning for the season of short days in the United States. For more from northern latitudes, follow @pedromcbride. #nature #arctic #Norway #midnightsun #silence
